title: Net neutrality in the United States
content:
{{Short description|ISP non-discrimination on internet data}} {{Net neutrality}} In the United States, [[net neutrality]]—the principle that [[Internet service provider]]s (ISPs) should make no distinctions between different kinds of content on the [[Internet]], and to not discriminate based on such distinctions—has been an issue of contention between end-users and ISPs since the 1990s.{{cite book |last1=Gilroy |first1=Angele A. |title=The Net Neutrality Debate: Access to Broadband Networks |date=April 15, 2019 |publisher=Congressional Research Service |location=Washington, DC |url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R40616.pdf |access-date=1 May 2019}}{{cite news |last=Lohr |first=Steve |title=Net Neutrality Is Trump's Next Target, Administration Says |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/30/technology/net-neutrality.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 30, 2017 |access-date=March 31, 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/09/business/media/09broadband.html|title=House Votes Against 'Net Neutrality|last=Wyatt|first=Edward|date=April 8, 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=September 23, 2011}} With net neutrality, ISPs may not intentionally [[IP address blocking|block]], [[Bandwidth throttling|slow down]], or charge different rates for specific online content.{{Cite journal |last1=Lee |first1=Daeho |last2=Hwang |first2=Junseok |date=2011-09-01 |title=Network neutrality and difference in efficiency among Internet application service providers: A meta-frontier analysis |url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0308596111001340 |journal=Telecommunications Policy |language=en |volume=35 |issue=8 |pages=764–772 |doi=10.1016/j.telpol.2011.07.005}} Without net neutrality, ISPs may prioritize certain types of traffic, meter others, or potentially block specific types of content, while charging consumers different rates for that content.{{Cite web|url=https://www.lawyersnjurists.com/article/network-neutrality/|title = Network Neutrality}} A core issue to net neutrality is how ISPs should be classified under the [[Communications Act of 1934]] as amended by the [[Telecommunications Act of 1996]]: as either Title I "[[information service (US law)|information services]]" or Title II "[[Common carrier#Telecommunications|common carrier services]]". The classification determines the [[Federal Communications Commission]]'s (FCC) authority over ISPs: the FCC would have significant ability to regulate ISPs if classified as common carriers, but would have little control over them if classified as information services. Because the Communications Act has not been amended by Congress to account for ISPs, the FCC has the authority to designate how ISPs are classified, as affirmed by the [[United States Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] in the case ''[[National Cable & Telecommunications Ass'n v. Brand X Internet Services]]'' (2005), in addition to choosing what regulations to set on common carriers. The five member FCC commission changes with each new administration, and no more than three members may be of the same political party, thus the FCC's attitudes and rule-making regarding net neutrality shifts relatively frequently. In the early 2000s, the FCC adopted a position that ISPs were Title I information services, and proposed net neutrality principles via the [[FCC Open Internet Order 2010]]. Courts ruled in ''[[Comcast v. FCC]]'' (2010) and ''[[Verizon Communications Inc. v. FCC (2014)|Verizon v. FCC]]'' (2014) that the FCC was not authorized to enforce these net neutrality principles on Title I information services. Under FCC chair [[Tom Wheeler]], the FCC voted in the 2015 FCC open order to categorize ISPs as Title II common carriers and thus subject to net neutrality principles, which was upheld after a legal challenge raised by the ISP industry in ''[[United States Telecom Association v. FCC (2016)|United States Telecom Ass'n v. FCC]]'' in 2016. During the [[First presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]], in 2017, the FCC reverted to handling ISPs as Title I information services with some court-mandated leeway being given to state-level legislation. In July 2021, President [[Joe Biden]] called for the FCC to undo some of these changes. In April 2024, the FCC voted 3-2 to restore net neutrality rules and regulation of Internet service providers.{{cite news |last1=Brodkin |first1=John |title=FCC moves ahead with Title II net neutrality rules in 3-2 party-line vote |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2023/10/fcc-moves-ahead-with-title-ii-net-neutrality-rules-in-3-2-party-line-vote/ |access-date=19 October 2023 |work=Ars Technica |date=19 October 2023}}{{Cite web |last=Feiner |first=Lauren |date=2024-04-25 |title=FCC votes to restore net neutrality |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/4/25/24140157/fcc-vote-restore-net-neutrality-rosenworcel-biden |access-date=2024-04-28 |website=The Verge |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=Fung |first1=Brian |title=Net neutrality is back as FCC votes to regulate internet providers |work=CNN |publisher=CNN |date=April 25, 2024 |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2024/04/25/tech/net-neutrality-is-back/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240712180127/https://edition.cnn.com/2024/04/25/tech/net-neutrality-is-back/index.html |archive-date=July 12, 2024}} In August 2024 a Federal court again blocked net neutrality rules.{{cite web |last1=Shepardson |first1=David |title=US court blocks Biden administration net neutrality rules |url=https://www.reuters.com/legal/us-court-blocks-biden-administration-net-neutrality-rules-2024-08-01/ |website=Reuters |access-date=21 August 2024}} ==Regulatory history== ===Early history 1980 – early 2000s=== {{Timeline of release years | title = Major events related to net neutrality in the United States | subtitle = Red: [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]]
Yellow: [[Obama administration]]
Green: [[First presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]]
Blue: [[Biden administration]] | align = right | compressempty = yes | range1 = 2001-2008 | range1_color = #ff0000 #800000 | range2 = 2009-2016 | range2_color = #ffff00 #cc9900 | range3 = 2017-2020 | range3_color = #33cc33 #009933 | range4 = 2021-2024 | range4_color = #0066ff #0000ff | first = 2003 | 2003 = Introduction of net neutrality concept | 2005 = ''[[National Cable & Telecommunications Association v. Brand X Internet Services]]'' | 2010a = ''[[Comcast Corp. v. FCC|Comcast v. FCC]]'' | 2010b = [[FCC Open Internet Order 2010]] | 2014 = ''[[Verizon Communications Inc. v. FCC (2014)|Verizon Communications Inc. v. FCC]]'' | 2015 = FCC Open Internet Order 2015 | 2016 = ''[[United States Telecom Association v. FCC (2016)|United States Telecom Ass'n v. FCC]]'' | 2018 = FCC "Restoring Internet Freedom"; net neutrality banned | 2019 = ''[[Mozilla v. FCC]]'' | 2021 = [[Executive Order 14036]], "Promoting Competition in the American Economy" | 2024 = Net neutrality officially restored by FCC | last = 2024 }} The ideas underlying net neutrality have a long pedigree in telecommunications practice and regulation. Services such as telegrams and the phone network (officially, the [[public switched telephone network]] or PSTN) have been considered [[common carrier]]s under U.S. law since the [[Mann–Elkins Act|Mann–Elkins Act of 1910]], which means that they have been akin to [[public utilities]] and expressly forbidden to give preferential treatment. The [[Communications Act of 1934]] created the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) to regulate the industry and ensure fair pricing and access.{{cite web|url=https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-12-92A1.pdf|title=Report and order|website=fcc.gov|access-date=26 September 2023}} Different titles of the Act covered different modes of communication, but primary focus on the debate of net neutrality has been on Titles I and II. The Act distinguished between common carriers, who were bound under Title II of the Act, and other telecommunication systems of the time, covered broadly under Title I. Within Title II, common carriers such as the phone networks were to be regulated by the FCC as to assure reasonable pricing rates and non-discriminatory practices. Systems under Title I were left to be unregulated by the FCC. In the late 1980s the Internet became legally available for commercial use, and in the early years of public use of the Internet, this was its main use – public access was limited and largely reached through [[dial-up modem]]s (as was the [[Bulletin board system]] dial-up culture that preceded it). The Internet was viewed more as a commercial service than a domestic and societal system. However, by the late 1990s and early 2000s, [[Internet in the United States|the Internet started to become common]] in households and wider society. Also in the 1980s, arguments about the public interest requirements of the telecommunications industry in the U.S. arose; whether companies involved in broadcasting were best viewed as community [[trustees]], with obligations to society and consumers, or mere [[Market (economics)|market]] participants with obligations only to their shareholders.[http://www.utexas.edu/law/journals/tlr/abstracts/Volume%2060/Fowler.htm Mark S. Fowler and Daniel L. Brenner, A Marketplace Approach to Broadcast Regulation, 60 Texas L. Rev. 207 (1982)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050114170542/http://www.utexas.edu/law/journals/tlr/abstracts/Volume%2060/Fowler.htm |date=January 14, 2005 }} is the definitive statement of this by the FCC chairman at the time, but this theory has been worked out extensively since. The legal debate about net neutrality regulations of the 2000s echoes this debate. By the 1990s, some U.S. politicians began to express concern over protecting the Internet: {{Blockquote|How can government ensure that the nascent Internet will permit everyone to be able to compete with everyone else for the opportunity to provide any service to all willing customers? Next, how can we ensure that this new marketplace reaches the entire nation? And then how can we ensure that it fulfills the enormous promise of education, economic growth, and job creation?|[[Al Gore]], 1994|{{cite web |url=http://artcontext.com/calendar/1997/superhig.html |title=Remarks as Delivered |publisher=Artcontext |date=January 11, 1994 |access-date=January 14, 2014}}}} The Communications Act of 1934 was amended with the [[Telecommunications Act of 1996]], which besides other provisions, defined "information services" as "the offering of a capability for generating, acquiring, storing, transforming, processing, retrieving, utilizing, or making available information via telecommunications", and covered only under Title I unregulated by the FCC.{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/104/plaws/publ104/PLAW-104publ104.pdf|title=Telecommunications act of 1996|website=congress.gov|access-date=26 September 2023}} In the early 2000s, legal scholars such as [[Tim Wu]] and [[Lawrence Lessig]] raised the issue of neutrality in a series of academic papers addressing regulatory frameworks for packet networks. Wu is credited with introducing the term "network neutrality" in his 2003 paper "Network Neutrality, Broadband Discrimination".{{Cite journal | author = Wu, T. | title = Network Neutrality, Broadband Discrimination | journal =Journal of Telecommunications and High Technology Law | year = 2003 |volume=2 |pages=141–179 | ssrn=388863}} Wu had found based on behaviors of broadband providers in the early 2000s that there could be potential for commercial interests to interfere with natural evolution of new innovations on the Internet, such as those using higher bandwidth like voice and video applications. Wu outlined the benefits and drawbacks of governmental regulation for net neutrality, writing "Communications regulators over the next decade will spend increasing time on conflicts between the private interests of broadband providers and the public’s interest in a competitive innovation environment centered on the Internet."{{cite web | url = https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/heres-paper-popularized-net-neutrality-180949376/ | title = Here's the Paper That Popularized Net Neutrality | first = Rachel | last = Nuwer | author-link = Rachel Nuwer | date = January 16, 2014 | accessdate = November 10, 2021 | work = [[Smithsonian Magazine]] }} Papers from Wu and others in the early 2000s sparked debate among academics in information technology and legal areas to device possible frameworks for net neutrality that could be applied within U.S. laws; these discussions paralleled similar concurrent ones in Europe, though due to its different governmental structure, took on different forms of implementation. Within the U.S., media and politicians learned of these regulatory suggestions, leading to the start of net neutrality principles within the government.[https://web.archive.org/web/20150908091323/http://www.im.uni-karlsruhe.de/Upload/Publications/3037fd45-29c8-4dcf-a417-850222ea771e.pdf Jan Krämer, Lukas Wiewiorra, Christof Weinhardt, Net Neutrality in the United States and Europe, CPI Antitrust Chronicle, March 2012(2)]{{cite journal | last1= Powell | first1= Alison | first2= Alissa | last2= Cooper | title = Net neutrality discourses: Comparing advocacy and regulatory arguments in the United States and the United Kingdom | journal = [[The Information Society]] | volume = 27 | issue = 5 | year = 2011 |pages= 311–325 | doi= 10.1080/01972243.2011.607034 | s2cid= 25827282 | url= http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/39024/ }} ===Attempts at regulation under Title I information services (2000–2015)=== ====''Brand X'' and FCC's authority to classify services (2000–2005)==== {{main|National Cable & Telecommunications Association v. Brand X Internet Services}} In the wake of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, the introduction of "information services" under Title I prompted many cable-based Internet access providers to urge the FCC to classify their services as Title I information services, rather than as cable providers under the Act's Title III which required them to provide open access to other service provides. The FCC took in comments, and after providing its initial findings in 2002, issued "Inquiry Concerning High-Speed Access to the Internet over Cable and Other Facilities" in which it had determined that cable ISPs were neither a telecommunications provider (under Title II) nor a cable provider (under Title III) but were solely an information service that fell under Title I and thus could operate unregulated by the FCC.{{cite journal | last = Aronowitz | first = Steven | title = Brand X Internet Services v. FCC: The Case of the Missing Policy Argument | journal = [[Berkeley Technology Law Journal]] | volume = 20 | date =2005 |pages= 887–905}} Several non-cable ISPs and other industry groups sued the FCC, challenging this ruling in multiple courts. The cases were consolidated to the [[Ninth Circuit]]. In May 2003, the Ninth Circuit vacated the FCC's ruling, stating that cable ISPs had a telecommunications function and thus should be regulated under Title II. The [[NCTA (association)|National Cable & Telecommunications Association]] challenged the ruling, and while the Ninth Circuit refused to rehear the case ''en banc'', the Supreme Court agreed to hear the case. The Court announced its judgment in June 2005. The 6–3 decision reversed the Ninth Circuit's ruling, deeming that the FCC had properly defined cable ISPs as an information service. The majority opinion relied on the [[Chevron deference|''Chevron'' deference]], a principle that the judicial body gives deference to an executive agency's interpretation of legislation outlining its granted powers as long as that interpretation is reasonable and consistent.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2019/10/4/20898779/fcc-net-neutrality-court-of-appeals-decision-ruling | title = The Court Allowed The Fcc To Kill Net Neutrality Because Washing Machines Can't Make Phone Calls | first = Nilay | last = Patel | date = October 4, 2019 | access-date = October 4, 2019 | work = [[The Verge]] }} While the ruling was unfavorable for proponents of net neutrality, ''Brand X'' established that the FCC had powers to classify Internet services subject to their interpretation, which has played a key role in how net neutrality has since played out in the United States with changing administrations.{{cite web | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2014/05/net-neutralitys-little-known-hero-antonin-scalia/361315/ | title = Antonin Scalia Totally Gets Net Neutrality | first= Robinson | last = Meyer | date = May 16, 2014 | access-date = October 4, 2019 | work = [[The Atlantic]] }} The majority opinion in Brand X was authored by Justice Clarence Thomas, who has subsequently stated that he regrets the decision, in his dissent to ''Baldwin v. United States''.{{Cite web |last=Brodkin |first=Jon |date=2020-02-26 |title=Clarence Thomas regrets ruling that Ajit Pai used to kill net neutrality |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2020/02/clarence-thomas-regrets-ruling-that-ajit-pai-used-to-kill-net-neutrality/ |access-date=2022-11-11 |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}} ====FCC promotes freedom without regulation (2004)==== In February 2004, then [[Federal Communications Commission]] Chairman Michael Powell announced a set of non-discrimination principles, which he called the principles of "Preserving Network Freedom", based on studies from Tim Wu and [[Phil Weiser]] and other academics from the previous years. Powell recognized that it was still early to have a clear picture of what government regulation should be for net neutrality, but agreed that based on practices of broadband operators of the past few years, it was necessary to establish what rights consumers should expect from broadband service. In a speech at the Silicon Flatirons Symposium, Powell encouraged ISPs to offer users these four freedoms:{{cite web |author=Powell, Michael |author-link=Michael Powell (attorney) |title=Preserving Internet Freedom: Guiding Principles for the Industry |url=http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DOC-243556A1.pdf |date=February 8, 2004 |access-date=July 7, 2006 |archive-date=May 19, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130519220745/http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DOC-243556A1.pdf |url-status=dead }} # Freedom to access content - Consumers should have access to their choice of legal content # Freedom to run applications - Consumers should be able to run applications of their choice # Freedom to attach devices - Consumers should be permitted to attach any devices they choose to the connection in their homes # Freedom to obtain service plan information - Consumers should receive meaningful information regarding their service plans In early 2005, in the ''Madison River'' case, the FCC for the first time showed the willingness to enforce its network neutrality principles by opening an investigation about Madison River Communications, a local telephone carrier that was blocking [[Vonage]]'s [[voice over IP]] (VoIP) service in its [[digital subscriber line]] (DSL) offering to customers. At the time, while the FCC classified cable providers under Title I as an information provider (as per the ''Brand X'' case) and were unregulated, services such as DSL were still considered under Title II as a common carrier, and were bound by non-discriminatory regulation from the FCC. Nevertheless, the FCC's investigation led to a settlement between the FCC and Madison River Communications before any further litigation occurred, with Madison River agreeing to stop blocking VoIP traffic and paying a {{USD|15,000|long=no}} fine.{{cite web |title=In the Matter of Madison River Communications, LLC and affiliated companies |url=http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DA-05-543A2.pdf |work=Consent Decree DA 05-543 |publisher=FCC |access-date=April 30, 2014 |year=2005 |archive-date=December 8, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208120436/http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DA-05-543A2.pdf |url-status=dead }} While the action did not set any precedent for the FCC's stance on net neutrality, the Madison River case was an indication the agency was willing to uphold Powell's principles.{{cite web |url=https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DA-05-543A2.pdf%7Cformat%3DPDF |title=Archived copy |access-date=April 22, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213153816/https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DA-05-543A2.pdf%7Cformat=PDF |archive-date=February 13, 2018 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }} Shortly after the case was settled, the FCC issued a new rule in 2005 to reclassified DSL as a Title I information service and allowing them to operate unregulated by the FCC.Appropriate Framework for Broadband Access to the Internet Over Wireline Facilities, Federal Communications Commission, {{Federal Register|70|60222}} (October 17, 2005){{cite journal | last = Reicher | first= Alexander | title = Redefining Net Neutrality After Comcast v. FCC. | journal = [[Berkeley Technology Law Journal]] | issue =26 | date = 2011 | pages = 733–764 }} ====CLEC, dial-up, and DSL deregulation (2004–2005)==== In 2004, the court case [[USTA v. FCC]] voided the FCC's authority to enforce rules requiring telephone operators to [[Local loop unbundling|unbundle]] certain parts of their networks at regulated prices. This caused the economic collapse of many [[competitive local exchange carrier]]s (CLEC).{{cite web |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/ogc/documents/opinions/2004/00-1012-030204.pdf |title=No. 00-1012 |author=United States Court of Appeals}} In the United States, broadband services were historically regulated differently according to the technology by which they were carried. While cable Internet has always been classified by the FCC as an information service free of most regulation, [[DSL]] was regulated as a [[telecommunications service]]. In 2005, the FCC reclassified Internet access across the phone network, including [[DSL]], as "information service" relaxing the common carrier regulations and unbundling requirement.{{cite web|url=https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-05-150A1.pdf |title=Federal Communications Commission Document|website=fcc.gov|access-date=26 September 2023}} During the FCC's hearing, the [[National Cable & Telecommunications Association]] urged the FCC to adopt the four criteria laid out in its 2005 Internet Policy Statement as the requisite openness. This made up a voluntary set of four net neutrality principles.{{cite web |author=Federal Communications Commission |author-link=Federal Communications Commission |title=New Principles Preserve and Promote the Open and Interconnected Nature of Public Internet |url=http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DOC-260435A1.pdf |date=August 5, 2005 |access-date=July 7, 2006 |archive-date=June 30, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060630155716/http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DOC-260435A1.pdf |url-status=dead }} Implementation of the principles was not mandatory; that would require an FCC rule or federal law.{{cite web |url=http://fjallfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-05-151A1.pdf |title=Before the Federal Communications Commission |publisher=Federal Communications Commission |access-date=January 14, 2014}} The modified principles were as follows:{{cite web |last=Isenberg |first=David |title=How Martin's FCC is different from Powell's |url=http://isen.com/blog/2005/08/how-martins-fcc-is-different-from.html |date=August 7, 2005 |access-date=July 7, 2006}}{{cite web |url=http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-05-151A1.pdf |title=Policy statement |publisher=Federal Communications Commission |access-date=August 26, 2009 |archive-date=August 19, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819190138/http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-05-151A1.pdf |url-status=dead }} # Consumers are entitled to access the lawful Internet content of their choice; # Consumers are entitled to run applications and services of their choice, subject to the needs of law enforcement; # Consumers are entitled to connect their choice of legal devices that do not harm the network; and # Consumers are entitled to competition among network providers, application and service providers, and content providers. In December 2006, the AT&T/Bell South merger agreement defined net neutrality as an agreement on the part of the broadband provider: "not to provide or to sell to Internet content, application or service providers ... any service that privileges, degrades or prioritizes any (data) packet transmitted over AT&T/BellSouth's wireline broadband Internet access service based on its source, ownership or destination."{{cite web |url=http://www.fcc.gov/ATT_FINALMergerCommitments12-28.pdf |title=Re : Notice of Ex Parte Communication in the Matter of Review of AT&T Inc . and BellSouth Corp Application For Consent to Transfer of Control, WC Docket No. 06-74 |publisher=Federal Communications Commissions |date=December 28, 2006 |access-date=January 14, 2014}} ==== ''Comcast v. FCC'' (2005–2010) ==== {{main|Comcast Corp. v. FCC}} In 2007, [[Comcast]], the largest cable company in the US, was found to be blocking or severely delaying [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]] uploads on their network using a technique which involved creating 'reset' packets ([[TCP/IP|TCP]] RST) that appeared to come from the other party.{{cite web |author=Cheng, Jacqui |title=Evidence mounts that comcast is targeting Bittorrent Traffic |url=https://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20071019-evidence-mounts-that-comcast-is-targeting-bittorrent-traffic.html |date=October 19, 2007 |publisher=Condé Nast |work=Ars Technica |access-date=November 15, 2014}} An August 2007 report by [[TorrentFreak]] (based on substantial nationwide research led by chief researcher [[Andrew Norton (Pirate Party)|Andrew Norton]]) noted that ISPs had been throttling BitTorrent traffic for almost two years, since 2005, but Comcast was completely blocking it in at least some cases.{{cite web |author=Ernesto |title=Comcast Throttles BitTorrent Traffic, Seeding Impossible |url=http://torrentfreak.com/comcast-throttles-bittorrent-traffic-seeding-impossible/ |date=August 17, 2007 |publisher=TorrentFreak BV |work=TorrentFreak |access-date=May 2, 2015}} This was later verified by both the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]]{{Cite news |url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2007/10/eff-tests-agree-ap-comcast-forging-packets-to-interfere |title=EFF tests agree with AP: Comcast is forging packets to interfere with user traffic |date=October 19, 2007 |work=Electronic Frontier Foundation|access-date=December 1, 2017 |language=en}} and [[Associated Press]].{{cite news |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gxRiQSVfgK4sLbVRE_X4MOlM9q0AD8SCASPG0 |title=The Associated Press: Comcast Blocks Some Internet Traffic |date=October 21, 2007 |access-date=December 1, 2017 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021020905/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gxRiQSVfgK4sLbVRE_X4MOlM9q0AD8SCASPG0 |archive-date=October 21, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} On March 27, 2008, Comcast and BitTorrent reached an agreement to work together on network traffic where Comcast was to adopt a protocol-neutral stance "as soon as the end of [2008]", and explore ways to "more effectively manage traffic on its network at peak times."{{cite news |title=Comcast, BitTorrent reached an agreement to work together on network traffic |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120658178504567453?mod=googlenews_wsj |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=March 27, 2008 |first=Vishesh |last=Kumar}} In December 2009, Comcast reached an out-of-court settlement of a class action lawsuit for {{dollarsign|USD}}16 million, admitting no wrongdoing{{cite news |author=Duncan, Geoff |title=Comcast to Pay $16 Million for Blocking P2P Applications |url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/comcast-to-pay-16-million-for-blocking-p2p-applications/ |date=December 23, 2009 |publisher=Digital Trends|access-date=December 23, 2009}} and amounting to no more than {{dollarsign|USD}}16 per affected account.{{cite news |author=Cheng, Jacqui |title=Comcast settles P2P throttling class-action for $16 million |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2009/12/comcast-throws-16-million-at-p2p-throttling-settlement.ars |date=December 22, 2009 |publisher=Condé Nast |work=Ars Technica|access-date=December 23, 2009}} In August 2008, the FCC made its first Internet network management decision.{{cite web |url=http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1788&context=btlj |title=THE FCC TACKLES NET NEUTRALITY: AGENCY JURISDICTION AND THE COMCAST ORDER |publisher=Berkley Technology Law Journal |access-date=January 14, 2014}} It voted 3-to-2 to uphold a complaint against Comcast ruling that it had illegally inhibited users of its high-speed Internet service from using [[file-sharing]] software because it [[Bandwidth throttling|throttled]] the bandwidth available to certain customers for video files to ensure that other customers had adequate bandwidth.{{cite news |url=https://www.theweek.com/article/index/87672/Toysafety_bill_advances_No_to_Internet_rationing |title=Toy-safety bill advances, No to Internet rationing |date=August 8, 2008|access-date=March 4, 2009 |work=The Week}}{{cite web |author=Kathleen Ann Ruane |author-link=Congressional Research Service |title=Net Neutrality: The Federal Communications Commission's Authority to Enforce its Network Management Principles |url=http://opencrs.com/document/R40234 |date=February 20, 2009| access-date=March 9, 2009 |format=PDF}} The FCC imposed no fine, but required Comcast to end such blocking in the year 2008, ordered Comcast to disclose the details of its network management practices within 30 days, submit a compliance plan for ending the offending practices by the end of the year, and disclose to the public the details of intended future practices. Then-FCC chairman [[Kevin J. Martin]] said the order was meant to set a precedent, that Internet providers and all communications companies could not prevent customers from using their networks the way they see fit, unless there is a good reason. In an interview Martin stated that "We are preserving the open character of the Internet" and "We are saying that network operators can't block people from getting access to any content and any applications."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/02/technology/02fcc.html |title=F.C.C. Vote Sets Precedent on Unfettered Web Usage |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |first=Saul |last=Hansell |date=August 2, 2008}} In two rulings, in April and June 2010 respectively, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]] ruled against the FCC; the April ruling denied to grant the FCC's request for a cease-and-desist order against Comcast related to BitTorrent transfers, while the June ruling vacated the FCC's order against Comcast. The U.S. Court of Appeals ruled that the FCC has no powers to regulate any Internet provider's network, or the management of its practices: "[the FCC] '''has failed to tie its assertion' of regulatory authority to an actual law enacted by Congress''",{{Cite web|last=Gross|first=Grant|date=April 26, 2010|title=Court rules against FCC's Comcast net neutrality decision|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/urnidgns002570f3005978d8852576fd00567528/court-rules-against-fccs-comcast-net-neutrality-decision-idUS386314786120100406|access-date=November 11, 2021|website=[[Reuters]]}}{{cite web|last=McCullagh|first=Declan|date=April 6, 2010|title=Court: FCC has no power to regulate Net neutrality|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13578_3-20001825-38.html|website=CNET}} and that the FCC lacked the authority under Title I to force ISPs to keep their networks open, while employing reasonable network management practices, to all forms of legal content.{{cite web |last=Ann Ruane |first=Kathleen |title=The FCC's Authority to Regulate Net Neutrality After Comcast v. FCC |url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R40234.pdf |publisher=Congressional Research Service|access-date=October 19, 2013 |date=April 29, 2013}} In wake of the rulings, the FCC stated it would continue its fight for net neutrality.{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2010/05/fcc-on-net-neutrality-yes-we-can.ars |title=FCC on net neutrality: yes we can |author=Matthew Lasar |work=arstechnica.com |publisher=Condé Nast |date=May 5, 2010|access-date=May 6, 2010}} ====FCC's conditions for spectrum auction (2008)==== In February 2008, [[Kevin Martin (FCC)|Kevin Martin]], then [[Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission]], said that he is "ready, willing and able," to prevent broadband ISPs from unreasonably interfering with their subscribers' access to content on the internet.{{cite news |title=FCC says will act on Web neutrality if needed |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/internetNews/idUSN2525077120080225 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=February 25, 2008}} In 2008, when the FCC [[United States 2008 wireless spectrum auction|auctioned off the 700 MHz block of wireless spectrum]] in anticipation of the [[DTV transition in the United States|DTV transition]], Google promised to enter a bid of $4.6 billion, if the FCC required the winning licensee to adhere to four conditions:{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/intl/en/press/pressrel/20070720_wireless.html |title=Google Intends to Bid in Spectrum Auction If FCC Adopts Consumer Choice and Competition Requirements |access-date=August 26, 2009}} * Open applications: Consumers should be able to download and use any software application, content, or services they desire; * Open devices: Consumers should be able to use a handheld communications device with whatever.. wireless network they prefer; * Open services: Third parties (resellers) should be able to acquire wireless services from a 700 MHz licensee on a wholesale basis, based on reasonably nondiscriminatory commercial terms; * Open networks: Third parties, such as Internet service providers, should be able to interconnect at any technically feasible point in a 700 MHz licensee's wireless network. These conditions were broadly similar to the FCC's Internet Policy Statement; FCC's applications and content were combined into a single bullet, and an extra bullet requiring wholesale access for third party providers was included. The FCC adopted only two of these four criteria for the auction, viz., open devices and open applications, and only applied these conditions to the nationwide C block portion of the band.{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/old/content/2007/07/fcc-sets-700mhz-auction-rules-limited-open-access-no-wholesale-requirement.ars |title=FCC sets 700 MHz auction rules: limited open access, no wholesale requirement |date=July 2007 |access-date=August 26, 2009}} President [[Barack Obama]]'s [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009]] called for an investment of $7.2 billion in broadband infrastructure and included an openness stipulation.{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216170759/http://appropriations.house.gov/pdf/PressSummary02-13-09.pdf |archive-date=2009-02-16 |url=http://appropriations.house.gov/pdf/PressSummary02-13-09.pdf |date=February 13, 2009 |title=Summary: American Recovery and Reinvestment |publisher=United States Committee on Appropriations}} ====FCC Open Internet Order (2010)==== {{Main|FCC Open Internet Order 2010}} Towards the end of 2009, the FCC began drafting new rules that would include a series of proposals that would prevent telecommunications, cable and wireless companies from blocking certain information on the Internet.{{cite journal |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/technology/2009/10/i_heart_the_new_fcc_chairman.html |title=VOIP over cellular connections|journal=Slate |date=October 9, 2009 |last1=Manjoo |first1=Farhad }} FCC Chair [[Julius Genachowski]] proposed to add two rules to the current FCC policy statement in 2005, viz., the nondiscrimination principle that ISPs must not discriminate against any content or applications, and the transparency principle, requiring that ISPs disclose all their policies to customers. He argued that wireless should be subject to the same network neutrality as wireline providers.{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2009/09/fcc-chairman-wants-network-neutrality-wired-and-wireless.ars |title=FCC Chairman wants network neutrality, wired and wireless |author=Nate Anderson |date=September 21, 2009 |access-date=October 6, 2009}} In October 2009, the FCC gave notice of proposed rule making on net neutrality.{{cite web |url=http://www.networkworld.com/news/2009/102209-fcc-net-neutrality.html |title=FAQ: What's the FCC vote on net neutrality all about? |author=Tim Greene |date=October 22, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617052424/http://www.networkworld.com/news/2009/102209-fcc-net-neutrality.html |archive-date=June 17, 2013 |df=mdy-all}} Following the ruling in ''Comcast v. FCC'' in March 2010, the FCC amended these rules to account for the court's decision. The FCC voted in December 2010 to approve the FCC Open Internet Order banning cable television and telephone service providers from preventing access to competitors or certain web sites. The order established six net "neutrality principles" that would apply to ISPs: * Transparency: Consumers and innovators have a right to know the basic performance characteristics of their Internet access and how their network is being managed; * No blocking: This includes a right to send and receive lawful traffic, prohibits the blocking of lawful content, apps, services and the connection of non-harmful devices to the network; * Level playing field: Consumers and innovators have a right to a level playing field. This means a ban on unreasonable content discrimination. There is no approval for so-called "pay for priority" arrangements involving fast lanes for some companies but not others; * Network management: This is an allowance for broadband providers to engage in reasonable network management. These rules do not forbid providers from offering subscribers tiers of services or charging based on bandwidth consumed; * Mobile: The provisions adopted today do not apply as strongly to mobile devices, though some provisions do apply. Of those that do are the broadly applicable rules requiring transparency for mobile broadband providers and prohibiting them from blocking websites and certain competitive applications; * Vigilance: The order creates an open Internet advisory committee to assist the commission in monitoring the state of Internet openness and the effects of the rules.{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2010/12/fcc-order/ |magazine=Wired |first=Sam |last=Gustin |title=FCC Passes Compromise Net Neutrality Rules |date=December 21, 2010}} The 2010 orders did not reclassify ISPs under Title II common carriers, leaving them unregulated by the FCC under Title I information services as a cumulative result of past FCC orders. The measure was denounced by net neutrality advocates as a capitulation to telecommunication companies such as allowing them to discriminate on transmission speed for their profit, especially on mobile devices like the [[iPad]], while pro-business advocates complained about any regulation of the Internet at all.{{cite news |url=http://www.thesunnews.com/2010/12/22/1881959/fcc-adopts-web-rules.html |title=FCC adopts web rules |last=Bartash |first=Jeffry |work=[[MarketWatch]]|date=December 22, 2010 |access-date=December 22, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717035844/http://www.thesunnews.com/2010/12/22/1881959/fcc-adopts-web-rules.html |archive-date=July 17, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |url=http://www.care2.com/causes/politics/blog/fcc-adopts-net-neutrality-rules/ |title=FCC Adopts Net Neutrality Rules |publisher=Care2.com |date=December 21, 2010 |access-date=January 14, 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/21/AR2010122106110.html |title=FCC Approves Net-Neutrality Rules; Criticism is Immediate |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=December 22, 2010 |access-date=September 23, 2011 |first=Cecilia |last=Kang|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905161027/https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/21/AR2010122106110.html|archive-date=September 5, 2017}} ====''Verizon v. FCC'' (2014)==== {{main|Verizon Communications Inc. v. Federal Communications Commission (2014)}} While the 2010 Open Internet Order was generally favorable to ISPs, the issuing of the neutrality principles that would still apply to Title I information services was criticized by some ISPs. [[Verizon Communications]] challenged the order at the [[D.C. Circuit]] court in early 2011, asserting that the FCC had overstepped its authority by applying principles to Title I information services. The D.C. Circuit ruled in January 2014 to vacate the blocking and discrimination principles from the 2010 Open Internet Order while upholding other parts. The decision determined that the FCC improperly relied on Section 706 of the amended Communications Act, which gives the FCC authority to incentivize the deployment of telecommunications services to all Americans including those in rural and low-income areas. The FCC had relied on Section 706's language that they had authority to "promulgate rules governing broadband providers’ treatment of Internet traffic" to apply these rules to Title I information services. The Court ruled that ISPs were still specifically treated as Title I information services by the FCC, and for the FCC to be able to regulate aspects like blocking or discrimination, they would specifically have to be cataloged as telecommunication common carriers under Title II. The court agreed that FCC can regulate broadband in a general manner and may craft more specific rules that stop short of identifying service providers as common carriers.{{cite web |last=Brodkin |first=Jon |title=Net neutrality is half-dead: Court strikes down FCC's anti-blocking rule |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2014/01/net-neutrality-is-half-dead-court-strikes-down-fccs-anti-blocking-rules/|access-date=January 14, 2014|date=January 14, 2014 }}{{cite web |last=Robertson |first=Adi |title=Federal court strikes down FCC net neutrality rules |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/1/14/5307650/federal-court-strikes-down-net-neutrality-rules |website=[[The Verge]]|access-date=January 14, 2014|date=January 14, 2014 }}{{cite journal | last = Wright | first = Christopher J. | title = The Scope of the FCC's Ancillary Jurisdiction after the DC Crcuit's Net Neutrality Decisions. | journal = [[Federal Communications Law Journal]] | volume = 67 | year =2014 | pages = 19–40 }} As a response to the DC Circuit Court's decision, a dispute developed as to whether net neutrality could be guaranteed under existing law, or if reclassification of ISPs was needed to ensure net neutrality.{{cite news |last=Berkman |first=Fran |date=May 20, 2014 |title=Title II is the key to net neutrality—so what is it? |url=http://www.dailydot.com/politics/what-is-title-ii-net-neutrality-fcc/ |newspaper=The Daily Dot|access-date=November 13, 2014}} Wheeler stated that the FCC had the authority under Section 706 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to regulate ISPs, while others, including President Obama,{{cite news |last=Wyatt |first=Edward |date=November 10, 2014 |title=Obama Asks F.C.C. to Adopt Tough Net Neutrality Rules |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/11/technology/obama-net-neutrality-fcc.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=November 13, 2014}} supported reclassifying ISPs as common carriers under Title II of the [[Communications Act of 1934]]. Critics of Section 706 point out that the section has no clear mandate to guarantee equal access to [[Content (media)|content]] provided over the internet, while subsection 202(a) of the Communications Act states that common carriers cannot "make any unjust or unreasonable discrimination in charges, practices, classifications, regulations, facilities, or services." Advocates of net neutrality have generally supported reclassifying ISPs under Title II, while FCC leadership and ISPs have generally opposed such reclassification. The FCC stated that if they reclassified ISPs as common carriers, the commission would selectively enforce Title II, so that only sections relating to broadband would apply to ISPs. ===Reclassification as Title II common carriers (2015–2017)=== ====Policy proposals (2014)==== [[File:Abandonment rate of online video users for different Internet connectivities.jpg|thumbnail|300px|Users with faster Internet connectivity (e.g., fiber) abandon a slow-loading video at a faster rate than users with slower Internet connectivity (e.g., cable or mobile).{{cite web |url=http://people.cs.umass.edu/~ramesh/Site/HOME_files/imc208-krishnan.pdf |title=Video Stream Quality Impacts Viewer Behavior |last1=Krishnan |first1=S. Shunmuga |first2=Ramesh K. |last2=Sitaraman |date=November 2012 |publisher=University of Massachusetts |access-date=February 28, 2015}} A "fast lane" in the Internet can irrevocably decrease the user's tolerance to the relative slowness of the "slow lane".]] On February 19, 2014, the FCC announced plans to formulate new rules to resume enforcing net neutrality while complying with the court rulings.{{cite web |url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9246443/FCC_will_set_new_net_neutrality_rules |title=FCC will set new net neutrality rules |author=Nancy Weil |date=February 19, 2014 |work=Computerworld |access-date=February 26, 2015}} However, in the event, on April 23, 2014, the FCC reported a new draft rule that would permit broadband ISPs such as [[Comcast]] and [[Verizon]] to offer content providers, such as [[Netflix]], [[Disney]], or [[Google]], willing to pay a higher price, faster connection speeds, so their customers would have preferential access, thus ''reversing'' its earlier position and (so far as opinion outside the ISP sector generally agreed) would ''deny'' net neutrality.{{cite news |last=Wyatt |first=Edward |title=F.C.C., in 'Net Neutrality' Turnaround, Plans to Allow Fast Lane |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/24/technology/fcc-new-net-neutrality-rules.html |date=April 23, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 23, 2014}}{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Creating a Two-Speed Internet |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/25/opinion/creating-a-two-speed-internet.html |date=April 24, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 25, 2014}}{{cite news |last=Carr |first=David |title=Warnings Along F.C.C.'s Fast Lane |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/12/business/media/warnings-along-fccs-fast-lane.html |date=May 11, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=May 11, 2014}}{{citation |title=In Policy Shift, F.C.C. Will Allow a Web Fast Lane |first=Edward |last=Wyatt |date=April 23, 2014 |access-date=April 23, 2014 |url=http://nyti.ms/1jPG7Uj |location=Washington, DC|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] }}{{citation |title=FCC to Propose New 'Net Neutrality' Rules: Proposal Would Allow Broadband Providers to Give Preferential Treatment to Some Traffic |first=Gautham |last=Nagesh |date=April 23, 2014 |access-date=April 23, 2014 |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304518704579519963416350296 |publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |location=Washington, DC}} Public response was heated, pointing out FCC chairman [[Tom Wheeler]]'s past as a president and CEO of two major ISP-related organizations, and the suspicion of bias towards the profit-motives of ISPs as a result. Shortly afterwards, during late April 2014, the contours of a document leaked that indicated that the FCC under Wheeler would consider promulgating rules allowing [[Internet service providers]] (ISPs) to violate [[net neutrality]] principles by making it easier for [[Internet]] users to access certain content — whose owners paid fees to the ISPs (including cable companies and wireless ISPs) — and harder to access other content,{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/24/technology/fcc-new-net-neutrality-rules.html |title=F.C.C., in a shift, backs fast lanes for web traffic |date=April 23, 2014 |access-date=May 8, 2014 |first=Edward |last=Wyatt |work=[[The New York Times]]}} thus undermining the traditional open architecture of the Internet. These plans received substantial backlash from activists, the mainstream press, and some other FCC commissioners.{{cite web |url=https://thehill.com/policy/technology/204366-nyt-blasts-net-neutrality-proposal/ |title=NYT blasts net neutrality proposal |first=Julian |last=Hattem |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=April 25, 2014 |access-date=May 8, 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://time.com/91619/net-neutrality-fcc-boss-smacked/ |title=Net Neutrality: FCC Boss Smacked by Tech Giants, Internal Dissent |date=May 7, 2014 |access-date=May 8, 2014 |first=Sam |last=Gustin |magazine=TIME}} In May 2014, over 100 Internet companies — including [[Google]], [[Microsoft]], [[eBay]], and [[Facebook]] — signed a letter to Wheeler voicing their disagreement with his plans, saying they represented a "grave threat to the Internet".{{cite news |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303701304579548364154205126 |title=Internet Companies, Two FCC Commissioners Disagree With Proposed Broadband Regulations |date=May 7, 2014 |access-date=May 8, 2014 |first=Gautham |last=Nagesh |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}} The FCC voted 3–2 on proposed rules to introduced tiered broadband allowances on May 15, 2014.{{cite magazine |url=https://time.com/101418/fcc-fast-lane-net-neutrality/ |title=FCC Votes to Move Forward on Internet 'Fast Lane' |last1=Edwards |first1=Haley Sweetland |date=May 15, 2014 |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=May 20, 2014}} Besides opening these rules to public comment prior to issuing a final ruling, the FCC asked the public on their opinion in regards to classifying ISPs as Title II common carrier telecommunication services. The public commenting period ran through July 2014,{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Searching for Fairness on the Internet |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/16/opinion/searching-for-fairness-on-the-internet.html |date=May 15, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=May 15, 2014}}{{cite news |last=Wyatt |first=Edward |title=F.C.C. Backs Opening Net Rules for Debate |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/16/technology/fcc-road-map-to-net-neutrality.html |date=May 15, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=May 15, 2014}} and garnering over one million responses, the most the FCC had ever received for rulemaking.{{cite news |last1=Hu |first1=Elise |title=1 Million Net Neutrality Comments Filed, But Will They Matter? |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/alltechconsidered/2014/07/21/332678802/one-million-net-neutrality-comments-filed-but-will-they-matter |access-date=July 23, 2014 |publisher=National Public Radio |date=July 21, 2014}} The FCC proposal for a tiered Internet received heavy criticism. Opponents argued that a user accessing content over the "fast lane" on the Internet would find the "slow lane" intolerable in comparison, greatly disadvantaging any content provider who is unable to pay for "fast lane" access. They argued that a tiered Internet would suppress new Internet innovations by increasing the barrier to entry. Video providers Netflix{{cite web |url=http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7522785302 |title=NetFlix comments to FCC, page 17, Sept 16th 2014 |access-date=December 13, 2014 |archive-date=November 29, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129021834/http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7522785302 |url-status=dead }} and Vimeo{{cite web |url=http://vimeo.com/assets/downloads/press_releases/07152014-vimeo_fcc_letter.pdf |title=Vimeo Open Letter to FCC, page 11, July 15th 2014}} in their comments filed with the FCC used the research of S.S. Krishnan and [[Ramesh Sitaraman]] that provided quantitative evidence of the impact of Internet speed on online video users. Their research studied the patience level of millions of Internet video users who waited for a slow-loading video to start playing. Users with faster Internet connectivity, such as fiber-to-the-home, demonstrated less patience and abandoned their videos sooner than similar users with slower Internet connectivity.{{cite web |url=http://www.roughtype.com/?p=2069 |title=Patience is a Network Effect, by Nicholas Carr, Nov 2012|date=November 11, 2012}}{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2013/01/10/168974423/in-video-streaming-rat-race-fast-is-never-fast-enough/ |title=NPR Morning Edition: In Video-Streaming Rat Race, Fast is Never Fast Enough, October 2012 |website=[[NPR]] |access-date=July 3, 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/style/2013/02/01/the-growing-culture-impatience-where-instant-gratification-makes-crave-more-instant-gratification/q8tWDNGeJB2mm45fQxtTQP/story.html?s_campaign=8315 |title=Instant gratification is making us perpetually impatient |date=February 2, 2013 |author=Christopher Muther |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |access-date=July 3, 2014}} Opponents of the tiered broadband rules declared September 10, 2014, to be the "Internet slowdown". Participating websites were purposely slowed down to show what they felt would happen if the new rules took effect. Websites that participated in the Internet slowdown included Netflix,{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2014/09/todays-net-neutrality-campaign-explained/379973/ |title=Why Netflix Is 'Slowing Down' Its Website Today |author=Rose Eveleth |author-link=Rose Eveleth |date=September 10, 2014 |work=[[The Atlantic]] |access-date=February 26, 2015}} [[Reddit]], [[Tumblr]], Twitter, [[Vimeo]] and [[Kickstarter]].{{cite web |url=https://www.battleforthenet.com/sept10th/ |title=Join the Battle for Net Neutrality |author=Fight for the Future |work=Battle for the Net |access-date=February 26, 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/sep/10/internet-slowdown-go-slow-google-youtube-net-neutrality |title=Battle for the net: why is my internet slow today? |author=Samuel Gibbs |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=September 10, 2014 |access-date=February 26, 2015}}{{cite journal |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Innovation/Horizons/2014/0910/Internet-Slowdown-Day-Why-websites-feel-sluggish-today |title=Internet Slowdown Day: Why websites feel sluggish today (+video) |author=The Christian Science Monitor |journal=The Christian Science Monitor |date=September 10, 2014 |access-date=February 26, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/2604318/internet-slowdown-day-becomes-an-online-picket-protest.html |title=Internet Slowdown Day becomes an online picket protest |author=Sharon Gaudin |date=September 10, 2014 |work=Computerworld |access-date=February 26, 2015}} The ''Economist'' described the "Battle for the Net [...] now casting the upcoming FCC decision as an epic clash between "Team Internet" (a plucky band of high-tech multi-millionaires) and "Team Cable" (a dastardly bunch of Big-ISP billionaires)."{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/babbage/2014/09/net-neutrality |author=M.H. |title=Net neutrality: Faux go-slow |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |date=September 10, 2014 |access-date=February 26, 2015}} On November 10, 2014, [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] stepped in, and recommended the FCC reclassify broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service in order to preserve [[net neutrality]].{{cite news |last=Wyatt |first=Edward |title=Obama Asks F.C.C. to Adopt Tough Net Neutrality Rules |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/11/technology/obama-net-neutrality-fcc.html |date=November 10, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=November 15, 2014}}{{cite news |author=NYT Editorial Board |title=Why the F.C.C. Should Heed President Obama on Internet Regulation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/15/opinion/why-the-fcc-should-heed-president-obama-on-internet-regulations.html |date=November 14, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=November 15, 2014}}{{cite web |last=Sepulveda |first=Ambassador Daniel A. |title=The World Is Watching Our Net Neutrality Debate, So Let's Get It Right |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/01/on-net-nuetrality-internet-freedom/ |date=January 21, 2015 |work=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |access-date=January 20, 2015}} [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] presented legislation in January 2015 in the form of a [[U. S. Congress]] [[United States House of Representatives|HR]] [[List of bills in the 114th United States Congress|discussion draft bill]] that made concessions to net neutrality but prohibited the FCC from accomplishing that goal, or from enacting any further regulation affecting ISPs, though the bill failed to be enacted.{{cite news |last=Weisman |first=Jonathan |title=Shifting Politics of Net Neutrality Debate Ahead of F.C.C.Vote |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/20/technology/shifting-politics-of-net-neutrality-debate-ahead-of-fcc-vote.html |date=January 19, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=January 20, 2015}}{{cite web |author=Staff |title=H. R. _ 114th Congress, 1st Session [Discussion Draft] – To amend the Communications Act of 1934 to ensure Internet openness... |url=http://energycommerce.house.gov/sites/republicans.energycommerce.house.gov/files/114/BILLS-114hr-PIH-OpenInternet.pdf |date=January 16, 2015 |work=[[U. S. Congress]] |access-date=January 20, 2015}} ====2015 Open Internet Order==== By January 2015, the FCC announced it had revised its prior rules and would be voting on a new preliminary ruling that defined ISPs as a Title II common carrier telecommunication service, with some necessary exemptions.{{cite news |last=Lohr |first=Steve |title=In Net Neutrality Push, F.C.C. Is Expected to Propose Regulating Internet Service as a Utility |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/03/technology/in-net-neutrality-push-fcc-is-expected-to-propose-regulating-the-internet-as-a-utility.html |date=February 2, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 2, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Lohr |first=Steve |title=F.C.C. Chief Wants to Override State Laws Curbing Community Net Services |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/02/f-c-c-chief-wants-to-override-state-laws-curbing-community-net-services/ |date=February 2, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 2, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Flaherty |first=Anne |title=Just whose Internet is it? New federal rules may answer that |url=http://apnews.excite.com/article/20150131/us--net_neutrality-news_guide-c235cbd2b9.html |date=January 31, 2015 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |access-date=January 31, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150201001057/http://apnews.excite.com/article/20150131/us--net_neutrality-news_guide-c235cbd2b9.html |archive-date=February 1, 2015 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |last=Fung |first=Brian |title=Get ready: The FCC says it will vote on net neutrality in February |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2015/01/02/get-ready-the-fcc-says-itll-vote-on-net-neutrality-in-february/ |date=January 2, 2015 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=January 2, 2015}}{{cite news |author=Staff |title=FCC to vote next month on net neutrality rules |url=http://apnews.excite.com/article/20150103/us-fcc-net-neutrality-d8f89ffc53.html |date=January 2, 2015 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |access-date=January 2, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103042904/http://apnews.excite.com/article/20150103/us-fcc-net-neutrality-d8f89ffc53.html |archive-date=January 3, 2015 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }} Adoption of this notion would reclassify Internet service from one of information to one of [[Telecommunications service provider|telecommunications]],{{cite news |last=Lohr |first=Steve |title=F.C.C. Plans Strong Hand to Regulate the Internet |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/05/technology/fcc-wheeler-net-neutrality.html |date=February 4, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 5, 2015}} treating it as a [[public good (economics)|public good]],{{cite news |last=Weisman |first=Jonathan |title=As Republicans Concede, F.C.C. Is Expected to Enforce Net Neutrality |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102452486 |date=February 24, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 24, 2015 |archive-date=February 25, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225051903/http://www.cnbc.com/id/102452486 |url-status=dead }}{{cite news |last=Lohr |first=Steve |title=The Push for Net Neutrality Arose From Lack of Choice |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/26/technology/limited-high-speed-internet-choices-underlie-net-neutrality-rules.html |date=February 25, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 25, 2015}} and ensure net neutrality, according to Wheeler.{{cite magazine |last=Wheeler |first=Tom |author-link=Tom Wheeler |title=FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler: This Is How We Will Ensure Net Neutrality |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/02/fcc-chairman-wheeler-net-neutrality |date=February 4, 2015 |magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |access-date=February 5, 2015}}{{cite news |author=The Editorial Board |title=Courage and Good Sense at the F.C.C. – Net Neutrality's Wise New Rules |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/06/opinion/net-neutralitys-wise-new-rules.html |date=February 6, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 6, 2015}} Ahead of the FCC's vote on these new rules, social media platforms had a large role on engaging the public in the debate surrounding net neutrality. Popular websites such as Tumblr, Vimeo, and Reddit also participated in the Internet slowdown on September 10, 2014, which the organization said was the largest sustained (lasting more than a single day) online protest effort in history.{{cite web |url=https://www.battleforthenet.com/sept10th/ |title=Sep 10th is the Internet Slowdown |access-date=March 2, 2015}} On January 26, 2015, popular blogging site Tumblr placed links to group Fight For The Future, a net neutrality advocacy group. The website displayed a countdown to the FCC vote on Title II on February 26, 2015. This was part of a widespread Internet campaign to sway congressional opinion and encourage users to call or submit comments to congressional representatives.{{cite web |url=http://tumblr.fightforthefuture.org/post/112237319673/breaking-grumpy-cat-soars-over-comcast |title=Breaking: Grumpy Cat Soars over Comcast Headquarters to say "Don't Mess With The Internet" |access-date=March 2, 2015}} Net neutrality advocacy groups such as Save the Internet coalition{{cite web |url=http://www.savetheinternet.com/sti-home |title=Save The Internet |access-date=March 2, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302020136/http://www.savetheinternet.com/sti-home |archive-date=March 2, 2015 |url-status=dead |df=mdy-all }} and Battle for the Net{{cite web |url=https://www.battleforthenet.com/ |title=Epic Victory at the FCC |access-date=March 2, 2015}} responded to the 2015 FCC ruling by calling for defense of the new net neutrality rules. The FCC voted 3–2 on February 25, 2015, to pass these new rules,{{cite news |author=Staff |title=FCC Adopts Strong, Sustainable Rules To Protect The Open Internet |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0226/DOC-332260A1.pdf |date=February 26, 2015 |work=[[Federal Communications Commission]] |access-date=February 26, 2015}}{{cite news |last1=Ruiz |first1=Rebecca R. |last2=Lohr |first2=Steve |title=In Net Neutrality Victory, F.C.C. Classifies Broadband Internet Service as a Public Utility |date=February 26, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/27/technology/net-neutrality-fcc-vote-internet-utility.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 26, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Flaherty |first=Anne |title=FACT CHECK: Talking heads skew 'net neutrality' debate |url=http://apnews.excite.com/article/20150225/us--net_neutrality-fact_check-e30cfb560f.html |date=February 25, 2015 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |access-date=February 26, 2015}} making exemptions for [[North Carolina]] and [[Tennessee]] where state laws had already established stronger net neutrality concepts, and would be willing to add exemptions for other states with similar laws.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.cio.com/article/2889633/fcc-votes-to-overturn-state-laws-limiting-municipal-broadband.html |title=FCC votes to overturn state laws limiting municipal broadband |first=Grant |last=Gross |agency=IDG News Service |magazine=CIO Magazine |date=February 26, 2015 |access-date=February 28, 2015 |archive-date=March 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150303125325/http://www.cio.com/article/2889633/fcc-votes-to-overturn-state-laws-limiting-municipal-broadband.html |url-status=dead }} In response to ISP and opponent views, Wheeler commented, "This is no more a plan to regulate the Internet than the First Amendment is a plan to regulate free speech. They both stand for the same concept."{{cite news |last=Liebelson |first=Dana |title=Net Neutrality Prevails in Historic FCC Vote |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/02/26/net-neutrality-fcc-vote_n_6761702.html |date=February 26, 2015 |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |access-date=February 27, 2015}} Full disclosure of the rules were released for public comment on March 12, 2015,{{cite news |last=Ruiz |first=Rebecca R. |title=F.C.C. Sets Net Neutrality Rules |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/13/technology/fcc-releases-net-neutrality-rules.html |date=March 12, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=March 13, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Sommer |first=Jeff |title=What the Net Neutrality Rules Say |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/03/12/technology/net-neutrality-rules-explained.html |date=March 12, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=March 13, 2015}}{{cite web |author=FCC Staff |title=Federal Communications Commission – FCC 15–24 – In the Matter of Protecting and Promoting the Open Internet – GN Docket No. 14-28 – Report and Order on Remand, Declaratory Ruling, and Order |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0312/FCC-15-24A1.pdf |date=March 12, 2015 |work=[[Federal Communications Commission]] |access-date=March 13, 2015}} and the final rule was published on April 13, 2015.{{cite web |last=Reisinger |first=Don |title=Net neutrality rules get published – let the lawsuits begin |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/fccs-net-neutrality-rules-hit-federal-register-lawsuit-underway/ |date=April 13, 2015 |work=[[CNET]] |access-date=April 13, 2015}}{{cite web |author=Federal Communications Commission |title=Protecting and Promoting the Open Internet – A Rule by the Federal Communications Commission on 04/13/2015 |url=https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2015/04/13/2015-07841/protecting-and-promoting-the-open-internet |date=April 13, 2015 |work=[[Federal Register]] |access-date=April 13, 2015|author-link=Federal Communications Commission }} ====''United States Telecom Ass'n v. FCC'' (2016)==== {{main|United States Telecom Association v. FCC (2016)}} Following the publication of the FCC's ruling in 2015, several internet providers filed suit to challenge the FCC's ruling. The cases were combined into a single case, ''[[United States Telecom Association v. FCC (2016)|United States Telecom Ass'n v. FCC]]'' 825 F.3d 674 (2016), heard by a three-judge panel on the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]] in December 2015.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump/trump-to-go-on-eight-state-blitz-ahead-of-election-day-idUSKCN1N02TZ | title = U.S. appeals court hears challenge to net neutrality rules | first =David | last = Shepardson | date = December 4, 2015 | access-date= October 26, 2018 | work =[[Reuters]] }} The court issued its decision in June 2016, with the panel split 2-1 in favor of maintaining the FCC's ruling, stating that the Internet should be treated as a utility and not as a luxury. Internet providers signaled their intent to continue to challenge this ruling to the Supreme Court.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/15/technology/net-neutrality-fcc-appeals-court-ruling.html | title = Court Backs Rules Treating Internet as Utility, Not Luxury | first= Cecelia | last = Kang | date = June 15, 2016 | access-date = October 26, 2018 | work = [[The New York Times]] }} Several of the telecom groups petitioned the Supreme Court for writ of [[certiorari]] following the Court of Appeals ruling, ultimately falling under the case name ''Berninger v. Federal Communications Commission'' (Docket 17-489). The petition argued that the FCC did not have the power to issue the Open Internet Order, which required a re-interpretation of the Communications Act of 1934, under the ''Chevron'' deference. On November 5, 2018, seven members of the Court denied the petition, leaving in place the Court of Appeals ruling, which established that the FCC had the ability to reclassify Internet under Title II. Chief Justice [[John Roberts]] abstained due to financial conflict, and Justice [[Brett Kavanaugh]] abstained due to his previous involvement with the case history. Three Justices, [[Clarence Thomas]], [[Samuel Alito]], and [[Neil Gorsuch]] had recommended accepting the petition as to order a ''Munsingwear'' vacatur, in which the Appeals Court order would have been vacated, returned to that court, and have the case rendered moot due to the more recent 2018 FCC order that reversed the Open Internet Order.{{cite web | url = http://www.scotusblog.com/2018/11/divided-court-denies-review-in-net-neutrality-cases/ |title = Divided court denies review in "net neutrality" cases | first = Amy | last =Howe | date = November 5, 2018 | access-date = November 5, 2018 | work = [[SCOTUSblog]] }}{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2018/11/supreme-court-wont-rule-on-legality-of-obama-era-net-neutrality-rules/ | title = Supreme Court rejects industry challenge of 2015 net neutrality rules | first= Jon | last =Brodkin | date = November 5, 2018 | access-date = November 5, 2018 | work = [[Ars Technica]] }} === Rollback to Title I information services under the first Trump administration (2017–2020) === ==== Restoring Internet Freedom proposed rules ==== [[File:Brendan Carr & Ajit Pai (26658680868).jpg|thumb|right|FCC Chairman [[Ajit Pai]] (center) has been at the forefront of the recent rollback of net neutrality rules.]] [[Donald Trump]] had been positioning himself for running for presidency as the FCC considered net neutrality and categorizing ISPs as Title II common carriers. He said in 2014, "Obama’s attack on the internet is another top down power grab. Net neutrality is the Fairness Doctrine. Will target conservative media."{{Cite tweet |last=Trump |first=Donald |date=November 12, 2014 |user=realDonaldTrump |number=532608358508167168 |access-date=December 7, 2017 |title=Obama's attack on the internet is another top down power grab. Net neutrality is the Fairness Doctrine. Will target conservative media.}}For a more recent commentary on this, see {{Citation |last=Snider |first=Mike |date=November 23, 2016 |title=Net neutrality, beloved by Netflix, looks headed for the ax under Trump |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/11/22/trump-team-appointees-indicate-net-neutrality-reversal/94266912/ |access-date=December 7, 2017}} Shortly after his inauguration in January 2017, President Trump appointed [[Ajit Pai]] as the new chairman of the FCC. Pai had previously been nominated to fill one of the required Republican seats on the commission by President Obama under the recommendation of Senate Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]].{{Citation |last=Pai |first=Ajit | editor-last = Pai| editor-first = Ajit |date=2017 |title=Ajit Pai, FCC Chairman |publisher=U.S. Federal Communications Commission |url=https://www.fcc.gov/about/leadership/ajit-pai |access-date=January 29, 2018}} Pai, who objected to the 2015 Open Internet Order, quickly began to roll back some of the policies that had been implemented by the FCC during the [[Obama administration]], and halted an investigation into the use of [[zero-rating]] by U.S. wireless providers. After his appointment, Pai stated that he planned to "modernize" FCC policies to "match the reality of the modern marketplace", but was unsure over whether the FCC would continue to enforce the net neutrality rules or Title II classification of broadband services established in the 2015 Open Internet Order.{{cite web |title=Ajit Pai on net neutrality: "I favor an open Internet and I oppose Title II" |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/01/fcc-chair-ajit-pai-wont-say-whether-hell-enforce-net-neutrality-rules/ |website=Ars Technica |date=January 31, 2017 |access-date=March 21, 2017}}{{cite news |last1=Kang |first1=Cecila |title=Trump's F.C.C. Pick Quickly Targets Net Neutrality Rules |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 5, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/05/technology/trumps-fcc-quickly-targets-net-neutrality-rules.html?_r=0 |access-date=March 21, 2017}} Pai stated his opposition to the current net neutrality rules as they were "regulating against hypothetical harms", rather than trying to correct actual anti-competitive behavior, and that there was no need for such wide-spread government intervention when there were only a few companies that may be harming consumers or innovators. Pai argued that net neutrality rules also would "prohibit a number of pro-competitive business arrangements" and "would reduce investments" into extending the Internet infrastructure.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/05/526916610/fcc-chief-net-neutrality-rules-treating-internet-as-utility-stifle-growth |title=FCC Chief Makes Case For Tackling Net Neutrality Violations 'After The Fact' |last=Selyukh |first=Alina, David Greene |date=May 5, 2017 |website=[[NPR]]|access-date=May 26, 2017}} By April 2017, Pai had indicated that the FCC would likely propose to roll back the 2015 Open Internet Order, reverting the classification of ISPs as Title II common carriers, and instead have ISPs to "voluntarily" commit to net neutrality principles, with violations to be covered by the [[Federal Trade Commission]] rather than the FCC.{{cite web |title=FCC chair wants to replace net neutrality with "voluntary" commitments |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/04/fcc-chair-wants-to-replace-net-neutrality-with-voluntary-commitments/ |website=Ars Technica |date=April 7, 2017 |access-date=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web |title=Ajit Pai's net neutrality plan is nonsense |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/7/15221326/ajit-pai-fcc-net-neutrality-bill-plan-nonsense |website=[[The Verge]] |date=April 7, 2017 |access-date=April 10, 2017}} On April 29, 2017, a clearer understanding of the latest net neutrality compromise proposal was described.{{cite news |author=The Editorial Board |title=F.C.C. Invokes Internet Freedom While Trying to Kill It |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/29/opinion/sunday/fcc-invokes-internet-freedom-while-trying-to-kill-it.html |date=April 29, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 29, 2017}}{{cite news |last=Reardon |first=Marguerite |title=Net neutrality redux: The battle for an open net continues – The Republican-led FCC is starting to roll back net neutrality rules. Here's what you need to know. |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/net-neutrality-redux-the-battle-for-an-open-net-continues |date=May 2, 2017 |work=[[CNET]] |access-date=May 2, 2017}} [[File:USTelecom1996-2015.svg|thumb|Broadband capital expenditures by U.S. broadband providers ($ billions, 1996–2015)]] On May 18, 2017, the FCC voted 2–1 to move forward with Pai's [[Notice of proposed rulemaking]] (NPRM) on "Restoring Internet freedom" rules{{Citation |title=Restoring Internet freedom |series=WC Docket No. 17-108 |publisher=Federal Communications Commission |url=https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-17-60A1.pdf |access-date=July 26, 2017}} by rolling back net neutrality regulations.{{cite web |url=https://money.cnn.com/2017/05/18/technology/fcc-net-neutrality-vote/index.html |title=FCC votes to move forward with net neutrality rollback |last=Fiegerman |first=Seth |date=May 18, 2017 |website=[[CNN]] Tech|access-date=May 26, 2017}} The new rules were published for public viewing on July 17, 2017.{{Citation |last1=Pai |first1=Ajit |last2=Clyburn |first2=Mignon L. |last3=O'Rielly |first3=Michael |date=May 17, 2017 |title=Restoring Internet Freedom with comments from commissioners |type=Notice of proposed rulemaking |work=WC Docket No. 17-108 |publisher=Federal Communications Commission of the United States government |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2017/db0523/FCC-17-60A1.pdf |access-date=June 11, 2017}} The FCC supported their rules by arguing that the classification of ISPs as Title II carriers had caused them to reduce their [[capital expenditure]]s in new infrastructure, threatening the future of the nation's telecommunication systems. The FCC cited a drop of approximately {{USD|1 billion|long=no}} in capital spending by telecoms between 2014 and 2015, based on data from the [[United States Telecom Association]] and similar figures from industry consultant [[Hal Singer]],{{Citation |last=Singer |first=Hal |date=March 1, 2017 |title=2016 Broadband Capex Survey: Tracking Investment in the Title II Era |publisher=Hal Singer |url=https://haljsinger.wordpress.com/2017/03/01/2016-broadband-capex-survey-tracking-investment-in-the-title-ii-era/ |access-date=July 28, 2017 |archive-date=July 27, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170727140424/https://haljsinger.wordpress.com/2017/03/01/2016-broadband-capex-survey-tracking-investment-in-the-title-ii-era/ |url-status=dead }} to demonstrate this. Analysts stated that the FCC had cherry picked this data, as about 75% of the annual changes in capital spending by telecoms between the period of 1996 to 2015 were decreases of at least {{USD|1 billion|long=no}}.{{Citation |author=Editorial Board |date=April 29, 2017 |title=F.C.C. Invokes Internet Freedom While Trying to Kill It |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/29/opinion/sunday/fcc-invokes-internet-freedom-while-trying-to-kill-it.html?_r=0 |access-date=July 28, 2017}}See also {{Citation |last=Crawford |first=Susan P. |date=April 27, 2017 |title=Ajit Pai is siding with the oligarchy -- and misleading Trump's base |publisher=Wired |url=https://www.wired.com/2017/04/ajit-pai-is-siding-with-the-oligarchy-and-misleading-trumps-base/ |access-date=July 28, 2017}} In her dissent to this NPRM, FCC Commissioner [[Mignon Clyburn]] wrote, "I have yet to see a credible analysis that suggests that broadband provider capital expenditures have declined as a result of our ''2015 Open Internet Order''. ...
