Using the same logic that the NPRM uses, one could suggest that the FCC's classification of cable modem service as an information service in 2002 resulted in an even more precipitous drop in broadband provider investment.”{{Citation |last=Clyburn |first=Mignon L. | editor-last = Pai| editor-first = Ajit | editor2-last = O'Rielly| editor2-first = Michael |date=May 18, 2017 |title=Dissenting statement of Commissioner Mignon L. Clyburn to Restoring Internet freedom |work=WC Docket No. 17-108 |publisher=U.S. Federal Communications Commission |pages=67–68 |url=https://apps.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/FCC-17-60A1.pdf |access-date=July 28, 2017}} Ernesto Falcon, Legislative Council for the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]{{Citation |last=Falcon |first=Ernesto Omar |title=Ernesto Falcon, Legislative Council |date=February 10, 2016 |publisher=Electronic Frontier Foundation |url=https://www.eff.org/about/staff/ernesto-omar-falcon |access-date=July 28, 2017}} claimed that no such claims of CapEx reductions have been made in official reports filed with the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC),{{Citation |last1=Graves |first1=Spencer B. |last2=Falcon |first2=Ernesto |date=July 25, 2017 |title=$15 minimum wage on Aug. 8 ballot in KCMO plus Trump's attack on net neutrality |publisher=KKFI |url=http://www.kkfi.org/program-episodes/15-minimum-wage-aug-8-ballot-kcmo-plus-trumps-attack-net-neutrality/ |access-date=July 28, 2017}} He said that major companies can be sued by investors who assert that they lost money because of misleading information in an SEC filing, and no such penalties apply to potentially misleading statements to Congress or the public. Falcon's claim is supported by an analysis by Turner of [[Free Press (advocacy group)|Free Press]] in a report that includes 26 figures and tables, 21 of which were extracted from SEC filings and three of the remaining five came from the U.S. Census Bureau's Annual Capital Expenditures Survey.{{Citation |last=Turner |first=S. Derek |date=May 2017 |title=It's Working: How the Internet Access and Online Video Markets Are Thriving in the Title II Era |publisher=Free Press |url=https://www.freepress.net/sites/default/files/resources/internet-access-and-online-video-markets-are-thriving-in-title-II-era.pdf |access-date=July 28, 2017}} The change since the Title II Order was negative for only 5 of Turner's 24 tables, and the mean and median change over the 24 tables for which it seemed reasonable to extract a typical annualized percentage change were 8.1% and 5.2%, respectively.See Turner (2017) and the summary of it in Table 1 in {{Citation | date = 2017-08-30 | title = Friends of Community Media Reply Comment in Opposition to Restoring Internet Freedom NPRM | publisher = U.S. Federal Communications Commission | url = https://www.fcc.gov/ecfs/filing/1083118363145 | access-date = 2017-08-31}} ==== Public commenting period and analysis of fraudulent activities ==== As required for any NPRM, a period for public commenting on the FCC's new proposed rules ran from May 18 to August 16, 2017. During the public commenting period, efforts were made by pro-net neutrality groups to get people to submit comments to the FCC in opposition to the new rules. [[John Oliver]], the host of ''[[Last Week Tonight]]'', encouraged his viewers to comment against the proposed FCC rules. In early June 2017, Battle for the Net, a coalition spearheaded by [[Fight for the Future]], [[Free Press (advocacy group)|Free Press Action Fund]], and [[Demand Progress]], announced a "massive day of action" for July 12.{{Citation |date=June 6, 2017 |title='Battle for the Net': Web Guardians Announce Global Day of Action to Defeat Trump's FCC |publisher=Common Dreams |url=https://www.commondreams.org/news/2017/06/06/battle-net-web-guardians-announce-global-day-action-defeat-trumps-fcc |access-date=July 27, 2017}} [[Day of Action to Save Net Neutrality|Over 50,000 websites, including multinational corporations]], participated in what Fight for the Future called "the largest online protest in history".{{cite magazine |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/3207564/internet/net-neutrality-the-july-12-internet-wide-day-of-action-protest.html |first=Haley |last=Velasco |title=Net Neutrality: What happened during the July 12 Internet-Wide Day of Action protest |magazine=PC World |date=July 11, 2017 |access-date=July 27, 2017}} The FCC's open comment period on the proposed language of "Restoring Internet Freedom" received about 21.9 million comments, the largest influx of public comments seen by the FCC at that time;{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/5/24/15682240/fcc-net-neutrality-proposal-sees-few-changes |title=2.6 million comments in, the FCC has changed almost nothing about its net neutrality proposal |last=Kastrenakes |first=Jacob |date=May 24, 2017 |website=[[The Verge]]|access-date=May 26, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.pewinternet.org/2017/11/29/public-comments-to-the-federal-communications-commission-about-net-neutrality-contain-many-inaccuracies-and-duplicates/|title=Public Comments to the Federal Communications Commission About Net Neutrality Contain Many Inaccuracies and Duplicates|date=2017-11-29|work=Pew Research Center: Internet, Science & Tech|access-date=2018-03-31|language=en-US}}{{cite web|url=http://www.emprata.com/reports/fcc-restoring-internet-freedom-docket/|title=FCC Restoring Internet Freedom Docket {{!}} Emprata|website=www.emprata.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-31}} previously the FCC had gotten about 500,000 comments related to [[Media cross-ownership in the United States|new media ownership rules]] in 2003 and 1.4 million comments from the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy]] in 2004.{{cite magazine | url = https://www.wired.com/story/fccs-broken-comments-system-could-help-doom-net-neutrality/ | title = FCC's Broken Comments System Could Help Doom Net Neutrality | first = Klint | last = Finley | date = September 2, 2017 | access-date = October 18, 2018 | magazine = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] }} As these comments were made available to the public, third-party groups began analyzing their contents, recognizing many comments that were against net neutrality shared the same language, and were considered to be duplicative. Analysis suggested that millions of these comments were fraudulent, using the same anti-net neutrality wording that had been proposed by the [[Center for Individual Freedom]].{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/5/10/15610744/anti-net-neutrality-fake-comments-identities |title=Anti-net neutrality spammers are impersonating real people to flood FCC comments |last=Lecher |first=Colin, Adi Robertson, and Russell Brandom |date=May 10, 2017 |website=[[The Verge]]|access-date=May 26, 2017}} One of the first studies performed after the closure of the public commenting period, done on behalf of Broadband for America, which sought to repeal the Obama-era rules, found that 60% of the comments were in favor of retaining the current rules. However, the study also identified a large number of duplicate comments; if these were taken out, the unique comments favoring retaining the current rules far outweighed those seeking repeal, 1.52 million to 23,000. During and after the public commenting period, analysts reviewed the public comments and observed that a significant proportion of those using boilerplate language in support of repealing the rules had used names and addresses off known spam databases, and of those who were willing and able to be contacts asserts they left no such comment for the FCC. At least twenty-four people listed by the FCC as giving anti-net neutrality comments signed an open letter to the FCC in May 2017 requesting the comments they were asserted to have made to be removed from public record. The FCC's system for public comments, the Electronic Comment Filing System (ECFS), came under scrutiny: it uses an open [[application programming interface]] (API), along keys to that provided by the FCC, to submit comments, making it exploitable for mass-messaging. In December 2017, the [[Pew Research Center]] issued its report in reviewing the comments, affirming that most of them were boilerplate messages, but representative of a mass campaign attempting to sway public policy. The Pew report did recognize that several of the names were nonsensical, such as variations of "John Smith", or used "The Internet", and in other cases, thousands of messages were received at nearly the same time, potential evidence of a bot spamming in comments.{{cite web | url = https://www.npr.org/2017/12/14/570262688/as-fcc-prepares-net-neutrality-vote-study-finds-millions-of-fake-comments | title = As FCC Prepares Net-Neutrality Vote, Study Finds Millions of Fake Comments | first = Brian | last =Naylor | date = December 14, 2017 | access-date = October 18, 2018 | work =[[NPR]] }} Another study evaluating all the comments submitted by the process was completed at [[Stanford University]] and published in October 2018. The Stanford study forced solely on unique comments, resulting in more than 800,000 comments that were called "semantic outliers" in contrast to boilerplate language, and in a detailed review of a sampling of one thousand of these, found that 99.7% favored retaining the Obama-era rules; these came from a geographically- and politically-diverse set of users.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/16/17984228/stanford-study-fcc-comments-net-neutrality| title = Stanford study says almost every unique FCC comment was pro-net neutrality | first =Colin | last = Lecher | date = October 16, 2018 | access-date = October 18, 2018 | work = [[The Verge]] }} Shortly after this study, [[Attorney General of New York|New York State's Attorney General]] [[Barbara Underwood]], one of the critics of the FCC's process, issued a subpoena to over a dozen advocacy groups on both sides of the net neutrality debate to determine if they had a role in the massive number of fraudulent comments left at the FCC's system.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/16/technology/net-neutrality-inquiry-comments.html | title = New York Attorney General Expands Inquiry Into Net Neutrality Comments | first =Nichalos | last = Confessore | date = October 16, 2018 | access-date = October 17, 2018 | work = [[The New York Times]] }} Other states, as well as the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], have issued similar subpoenas on the commenting period.{{cite web | url = https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/kevincollier/feds-investigation-net-neutrality-comments | title = Millions Of Comments About The FCC's Net Neutrality Rules Were Fake. Now The Feds Are Investigating. | first1= Kevin | last1 = Collier | first2= Jeremy | last2= Singer-Vine | date = December 8, 2018 | access-date = December 8, 2018 | work = [[Buzzfeed News]] }} Both ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[BuzzFeed]]'' had filed [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] (FOIA) requests to the FCC to gain information on the IP addresses used in the public comment period. The FCC denied the requests in December 2018 citing that releasing this information would leave the US vulnerable to a cyberattack, and Pai wrote in an attached statement that at least 500,000 of the comments were tied to Russian addresses, interfering in the process and trying to swing the public opinion in favor of keeping the Obama-era net neutrality rules.{{cite web | url = https://thehill.com/policy/technology/419846-fcc-chairman-acknowledges-russia-interfered-in-net-neutrality-public/ | title = FCC chairman acknowledges Russia interfered in net neutrality public comments | first = Emily | last =Brimbaum | date = December 5, 2018 | access-date = December 5, 2018 | work = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] }} A separate FOIA request was made by ''The New York Times'' as well as the website ''[[Gizmodo]]'' for records pertaining to the API key logs from the ECFS, which were granted after journalists from the works filed suit against the FCC's initial denial.{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2019/03/fcc-has-to-pay-journalist-43000-after-hiding-net-neutrality-records/ | title= FCC has to pay journalist $43,000 after hiding net neutrality records | first = Jon | last =Brodkin | date = March 22, 2019 | access-date = March 27, 2019 | work = [[Ars Technica]] }} Data analysis led by ''The New York Times'' and ''Gizmodo'' to review the logs against those of the duplicated comments. They concluded that the duplicated comments were coming from submissions through the API assigned to [[Roll Call|CQ Roll Call]], which does offer advocacy software to clients for this purpose. ''Gizmodo'' found the comments tied to the name of those that had signed the May 2017 open letter to the FCC, matching this pattern. Separately, ''Gizmodo'' found the language of the duplicated comments shares many similarities with statements made by the [[Center for Individual Freedom]] (CFIF), which had been outspoken against net neutrality of the page. Due to these investigations, CQ Roll Call, CFIF, and several other advocacy groups with access to CQ Roll Call's had been called for questioning within the New York State case against the FCC.{{Cite web | url = https://gizmodo.com/how-an-investigation-of-fake-fcc-comments-snared-a-prom-1832788658 | title = How an Investigation of Fake FCC Comments Snared a Prominent D.C. Media Firm | first1 = Dell | last1 =Cameron | first2= Jason | last2 = Pretchel | date = February 21, 2019 | access-date = March 27, 2019 |work = [[Gizmodo]] }} In May 2020, Judge [[Lorna G. Schofield]] of the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] ruled that the FCC must provide ''The New York Times'' the IP addresses of all the comments from this commenting period. Judge Schofield stated that despite the FCC's claims of privacy issues, the request by the newspaper was valid to examine if any fraudulent activity interfered during the public commenting period towards the issue if the FCC's decision to repeal was "vulnerable to corruption".{{cite web | url = https://gizmodo.com/judge-orders-fcc-to-hand-over-ip-addresses-linked-to-fa-1843202071 | title = Judge Orders FCC to Hand Over IP Addresses Linked to Fake Net Neutrality Comments | first= Dell | last =Cameron | date = May 1, 2020 | access-date = May 1, 2020 | work = [[Gizmodo]] }} The New York state attorney general's office reported in May 2021 that after evaluating the comments, they determined that about 18 million of the 21.9 million submitted were bogus. About 8.5 million of those comments were tied to co-registration promotions put forth by the telecom industry, promising consumers gift cards or entry into sweepstakes but then using their names and information to submit the comments without their knowledge. For this, the office had already reached settlement deals with three telecom companies for a total of {{USD|4 million|long=no}} in fines. Another 9.3 million of the comments considered bogus were in favor of net neutrality, according to the report, filed under false identities and many submitted by a single person.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/6/22422818/net-neutrality-rollback-ajit-pai-telecom-broadband-new-york-attorney-general | title = FCC's net neutrality rollback overwhelmed by bogus industry comments, investigation finds | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = May 6, 2021 | accessdate = May 6, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] }}{{cite report | url = https://ag.ny.gov/sites/default/files/oag-fakecommentsreport.pdf | title = Fake Comments: How U.S. Companies & Partisans Hack Democracy to Undermine Your Voice | date = May 6, 2021 | accessdate = May 6, 2021 | publisher = New York State Office of the Attorney General Letitia James }} The attorney general also obtained a total of {{USD|650,000}} from three influencer companies paid by the telecom industry that participated in the millions of fake responses.{{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/new-york-ag-fines-companies-that-spammed-fcc-with-fake-anti-net-neutrality-comments-152249081.html | title = New York AG fines companies that spammed FCC with fake anti-net neutrality comments | first = Jon | last = Fingas | date = May 11, 2023 | accessdate = May 13, 2023 | work = [[Engadget]] }} ====Enactment of the new order==== Despite the ongoing analysis into fraudulent activities related to the public commenting period, and that the public comments that were deemed legitimate that weighed in favor of maintaining the 2015 Open Internet Order, the FCC announced in November 2017 that it was planning to go ahead with a final vote on December 14, 2017, to vote in the Restore Internet Freedom order and repeal the net neutrality rules.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-internet-exclusive/exclusive-u-s-agency-to-vote-to-repeal-net-neutrality-rules-fcc-chief-idUSKBN1DL21A |title=FCC chief plans to ditch U.S. 'net neutrality' rules |date=November 22, 2017 |access-date=November 21, 2017 |work=[[Reuters]]}} FCC commissioner [[Jessica Rosenworcel]] alleged on December 8 that the FCC was [[Obstruction of justice|withholding evidence of fraud]] due to irregularities in its comment period and said the vote should be postponed until after an appropriate investigation.{{Cite news |url=https://gizmodo.com/fcc-commissioner-blasts-her-own-agency-for-withhold-evi-1821133018|title=FCC Commissioner Blasts Her Own Agency for Withholding Evidence of Fraud|last=Cameron|first=Dell|work=Gizmodo|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}} Many organizations involved in the July 12 Day of Action planned an online protest for December 12.{{cite web |url=https://gizmodo.com/the-internet-blackout-for-net-neutrality-is-coming-and-1821186037 |title=The Internet blackout for net neutrality is coming and you can help |first=Rhett |last=Jones |website=Gizmodo |date=December 10, 2017 |access-date=December 12, 2017}} A vote was held on December 14, 2017, with a 3–2 party-line vote approving the repeal.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/21/technology/fcc-net-neutrality.html |title=F.C.C. Plans Net Neutrality Repeal in a Victory for Telecoms |first=Cecilia |last=Kang |date=November 21, 2017 |access-date=November 21, 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2017/11/21/the-fcc-has-unveiled-its-plan-to-rollback-its-net-neutrality-rules/ |title=FCC plan would give Internet providers power to choose the sites customers see and use |first=Brian |last=Fung |date=November 21, 2017 |access-date=November 21, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}} On January 4, 2018, the current version of "Restoring Internet freedom" was made public,{{Citation | last = Brodkin | first = Jon | date = 2018-01-04 | title = FCC releases final net neutrality repeal order, three weeks after vote: With repeal officially published, FCC will soon face lawsuits. | publisher = Ars Technica | url = https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2018/01/fcc-releases-final-net-neutrality-repeal-order-three-weeks-after-vote/ | access-date= 2018-01-05}} and was officially codified in the [[Federal Register]] on February 22, 2018,{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2018/02/22/net-neutrality-clock-ticking-those-who-want-old-rules-back/357985002/|title=22 states and DC are suing the FCC in last-ditch effort to preserve net neutrality|last=Snider|first=Mike|date=February 22, 2018|work=[[USA Today]]|access-date=February 23, 2018}} with the rules taking effect on June 11, 2018.[https://mobile.nytimes.com/2018/06/11/technology/net-neutrality-repeal.html The Net Neutrality Repeal Is Official], Keith Collins, New York Times, June 11, 2018 The FCC voted along party lines, 3–2, on December 14, 2017, to enact the Restoring Internet freedom rules and repeal the 2015 Open Internet Order.{{cite news |last=Fung |first=Brian |title=The FCC just voted to repeal its net neutrality rules, in a sweeping act of deregulation |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2017/12/14/the-fcc-is-expected-to-repeal-its-net-neutrality-rules-today-in-a-sweeping-act-of-deregulation/ |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=December 14, 2017|access-date=December 14, 2017 |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}} ====''Mozilla v. FCC'' (2017–2019)==== {{main|Mozilla v. FCC}} Within minutes after the FCC vote on December 14, 2017, [[Attorney General of New York|New York Attorney General]] [[Eric Schneiderman]] announced his intent to lead a multi-state lawsuit against the FCC to "stop illegal rollback of net neutrality".{{cite news |last1=Griswold |first1=Alison |title=The first lawsuit to save net neutrality was announced minutes after the FCC voted to repeal it |url=https://qz.com/1157178/us-state-attorneys-general-are-already-suing-to-save-net-neutrality-from-the-fcc/ |work=Quartz |access-date=December 14, 2017 |date=December 14, 2017}} [[Washington Attorney General]] [[Bob Ferguson (politician)|Bob Ferguson]] also stated his intent to sue. Twenty-two states and the District of Columbia, led by New York's Schneiderman, filed a formal suit in the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]] against the FCC's ruling on January 16, 2018, calling it "arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion", and that the FCC mis-classified Internet access as a Title I service rather than Title II due to "an erroneous and unreasonable interpretation" of laws around communication services.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2018/1/16/16898352/attorneys-general-lawsuit-fcc-net-neutrality | title = 22 attorneys general sue to block net neutrality rollback | first = Colin | last = Lecher | date = January 16, 2018 | access-date = October 12, 2018 | work = [[The Verge]] }} The initial filing was withdrawn in early February 2018 only due to the fact that the FCC's ruling had not yet been published within the [[Federal Register]]. Once the new FCC rules were published in February 2018, the states, District of Columbia, joined by the [[Mozilla Foundation]] and [[Vimeo]], and several other state and local entities and advocacy groups, refiled the suit on February 22, 2018.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-internet/states-refile-lawsuits-to-block-repeal-of-u-s-net-neutrality-idUSKCN1G62F8 | title = States refile lawsuits to block repeal of U.S. net neutrality | first = David | last =Shepherdson | date = February 22, 2018 | access-date = October 12, 2018 | work = [[Reuters]] }} The cases were all consolidated under the title ''Mozilla v. FCC''. The FCC issued its defense on October 12, 2018, requesting the Court to reject the lawsuit, as the lawsuit filed brings "no substantial reason to second-guess the commission’s decision to eliminate rules that the agency has determined are both unlawful and unwise".{{cite news | url = https://ca.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idCAKCN1MM242-OCATC | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181013053731/https://ca.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idCAKCN1MM242-OCATC | url-status = dead | archive-date = October 13, 2018 | title = U.S. defends FCC's repeal of net neutrality rules | first = David | last =Shepherdson | date = October 12, 2018 | access-date = October 12, 2018 | work = [[Reuters]] }} Initial court hearings were held on February 1, 2019. The FCC had requested a rescheduling of the hearings due to lack of resources created by the [[United States federal government shutdown of 2018–2019|ongoing shutdown of the government]],{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2019/01/fcc-asks-court-for-delay-in-case-that-could-restore-net-neutrality-rules/ | title = FCC asks court for delay in case that could restore net neutrality rules | first = Jon | last =Brodkin | date = January 16, 2019 | access-date = January 17, 2019 | work = [[Ars Technica]] }} but this request was denied by the D.C. District Court.{{cite web | url = https://thehill.com/policy/technology/425926-court-rejects-fcc-request-to-delay-net-neutrality-case/ | title = Court rejects FCC request to delay net neutrality case | first = Harper | last = Neidig | date = January 17, 2019 | access-date = January 17, 2019 | work = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] }} At the hearing before three judges, the states challenging the FCC not only discussed the issues related to net neutrality, but also charged the FCC with selectively reviewing the public comments to come to its decision, thus "failed in its responsibility to engage in reasoned decision-making".{{cite web | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-02-01/net-neutrality-advocates-seeking-rule-revival-get-day-in-court | title = Net Neutrality Advocates Seeking Rule Revival Get Day in Court | first1 = Andrew | last1 = Harris | first2= Todd | last2 = Shields | date = February 1, 2019 | access-date = February 1, 2019 | work = [[Bloomberg L.P.]] }} ISPs argued the need to have an unregulated approach to providing high-quality services to their users, and that they would not be able to offer anything less than the full Internet to users given the competitive landscape. The Court of Appeals issued its decision on October 1, 2019. In a multipart decision, the Court ruled that the FCC has the capability to reclassify Internet service under Title I based on the prior ''Brand X'' ruling from the Supreme Court, allowing its 2017 rule change to stand. However, the opinion stated that the FCC had "disregard of its duty" in evaluating the impact of net neutrality on public safety, using the example of throttled communications that impacted the capabilities of first responders during the [[Camp Fire (2018)|2018 Camp Fire]]. The opinion also stated that the FCC had not addressed how these rules affected utility pole access or other programs like the low-income [[Lifeline (FCC program)|Lifeline program]]. The Court did rule against the FCC, vacating the rule's limitations against state-level actions to enforce net neutrality as Congress had not given the FCC any such authority via the Telecommunications Act.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2019/10/1/20893342/fcc-net-neutrality-repeal-dc-appeals-court-ruling-state-law-preemption | title = The FCC can repeal net neutrality, but it can't block state laws, says court | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = October 1, 2019 | access-date= October 1, 2019 | work = [[The Verge]] }}{{cite news| last=Romm | first=Tony | title=Appeals court ruling upholds FCC's canceling of net neutrality rules | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=2019-10-01 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/10/01/appeals-court-upholds-trump-administrations-cancelling-net-neutrality-rules/ }}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fcc-rollback-of-net-neutrality-rules-is-partly-upheld-by-appeals-court-11569942446|title=FCC Rollback of Net Neutrality Rules is Partly Upheld by Appeals Court|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=October 2019}} While various parts in support of the plaintiffs requested an [[en banc]] hearing from the full Court of Appeals, the Court denied this in February 2020.{{cite web | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-internet/us-appeals-court-will-not-reconsider-net-neutrality-repeal-ruling-idUSKBN20032K | title = U.S. appeals court will not reconsider net neutrality repeal ruling | first = David | last =Shepardson | date = February 6, 2020 | access-date = February 6, 2020 | publisher=[[Reuters]]}} ====2018 US Senate vote==== In January 2018, fifty [[United States Senate|United States senators]] endorsed legislative action under the [[Congressional Review Act]] (CRA) to reverse the repeal of Title II net neutrality.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2018/01/15/the-senates-push-to-overrule-the-fcc-on-net-neutrality-now-has-50-votes-democrats-say/|title=The Senate's push to overrule the FCC on net neutrality now has 50 votes, Democrats say|last=Fung|first=Brian|date=2018-01-15|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=2018-01-22|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} While the effort was pushed by Democratic Senators, they had also gained support of three Republican Senators, [[Susan Collins]], [[Lisa Murkowski]], and [[John Kennedy (Louisiana politician)|John Kennedy]].{{cite web|url=https://www.markey.senate.gov/news/press-releases/senator-markey-leads-resolution-to-restore-fccs-net-neutrality-rules|title=Senator Markey Leads Resolution to Restore FCC's Net Neutrality Rules|date=2017-12-14|access-date=2018-05-17}} The motion to restore net neutrality passed in the Senate on May 16, 2018.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/16/politics/net-neutrality-vote-senate-democrats/index.html|title=Senate passes measure repealing changes to net neutrality rules|first1=Ted|last1=Barrett|first2=Daniella|last2=Diaz|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=2018-05-16|access-date=2018-05-17}}{{cite web | url = https://www.politico.com/story/2018/05/16/senate-democrats-net-neutrality-539275 | title = Senate Democrats win net neutrality showdown | first= John | last = Hendal | date = May 16, 2018 | access-date = May 16, 2018 | work = [[Politico]] }} However, efforts for the House of Representatives to pass similar legislative action through the CRA had stalled; Democratic Representatives had attempted to gain sufficient signatures for a [[discharge petition]] to force the vote on the matter, but by June 2018, were still 46 signatures short, principally along partisan lines.{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2018/06/bill-to-save-net-neutrality-is-46-votes-short-in-us-house/ | title = Bill to save net neutrality is 46 votes short in US House | first= Jon | last =Brodkin | date = June 27, 2018 | access-date = October 26, 2018 | work = [[Ars Technica]] }} While the revised FCC order repealing net neutrality has become official as of June 11, 2018, the House could have taken action to reverse the decision, but even with CRA passage, the action would have to be signed into law by the President.{{cite web | url = https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/net-neutrality-congressional-review-act/ | title = What is the Congressional Review Act, and how is it being used to try and save net neutrality? | first = Andrew | last = Welch | date = October 1, 2018 | access-date = October 26, 2018 | work = [[The Daily Dot]] }} However, the Congressional term ended before the House of Representatives could act, preventing the CRA challenge. ====California net neutrality law (2018)==== {{Main|California Internet Consumer Protection and Net Neutrality Act of 2018}} While various states have enacted versions of net neutrality laws, these mostly have been working within the established parameters set by the FCC. In the FCC's rollback, the ruling includes language that asserts states do not have authority to override the FCC decision. Legal experts believe this clause to be flawed and would allow states to still override the FCC's decision on net neutrality, as the language divests the FCC from regulating broadband carriers, and thus would disallow them from preventing states from regulating them.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/2/17927430/california-net-neutrality-law-preemption-state-lawsuit | title = Why feds can't block California's net neutrality bill | first= Karl | last =Bode | date = October 2, 2018 | access-date = October 26, 2018 | work = [[The Verge]] }} Following the FCC's revocation of all net neutrality protections, California State Senator Scott Wiener introduced SB822, which comprehensively restored all of the protections of the 2015 Open Internet Order. The bill passed with bi-partisan support in both the State Assembly and State Senate, and on September 30, 2018, Governor [[Jerry Brown]] signed it into law. On the same day as it was signed, the US Department of Justice sued the state of California to stop the law, arguing that Congress granted the FCC the sole authority to create rules for broadband internet providers.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/30/technology/net-neutrality-california.html | title = Justice Department Sues to Stop California Net Neutrality Law | first = Cecilia | last = Kang | date = September 30, 2018 | access-date = October 3, 2018 | work = [[The New York Times]] }} A few days later, four lobbying groups that represent the major United States terrestrial and mobile communication carriers, [[United States Telecom Association]], [[CTIA (organization)|CTIA]], [[NCTA (association)|NCTA]] and the American Cable Association, also sued the state of California for similar reasons as the Justice Department, claiming that the state does not have authority to regulate Internet providers.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/3/17933804/net-neutrality-california-bill-broadband-isp-sb822 | title= Broadband industry groups sue California over net neutrality bill | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = October 3, 2018 | access-date = October 3, 2018 | work = [[The Verge]] }} The state and the FCC announced on October 26, 2018, that they have reached agreement for California to hold off the enforcement of the law until pending legal action over the FCC's decision. Despite not being enforced, the bill went into effect on January 1, 2019.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/26/18029226/net-neutrality-fcc-california-law-ajit-pai-scott-wiener | title = California strikes deal with FCC to delay state net neutrality law | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = October 26, 2018 | access-date = October 26, 2018 | work = [[The Verge]] }} With the October 2019 decision in ''Mozilla v. FCC'' that overturned the 2017 Order's blanket ban on state net neutrality, the U.S. government and the ISP trade groups restarted their lawsuit in August 2020 and are seeking a preliminary injunction to block enforcement of California's law until the case is concluded.{{cite web | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-internet-idUSKCN2512WM | title = U.S. Justice Department asks court to block California net neutrality law | first = David | last = Shepardson | date = August 6, 2020 | access-date = August 6, 2020 | publisher = [[Reuters]] }} However, following the election of [[Joe Biden]] as president in 2021, Biden's new Department of Justice withdrew from the challenge, leaving the ISP trade groups to continue the suit.{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2021/digital/news/biden-net-neutrality-department-of-justice-1234903450/ | title = Biden's Justice Department Drops Legal Challenge to California Net Neutrality Law | first = Gene | last = Maddaus | date = February 8, 2021 | access-date = February 8, 2021 | work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] }} Subsequently, the judge denied the preliminary injunction in a ruling on February 23, 2021, allowing the California law to go into effect, on the basis that the ISP trade groups will be unlikely to prevail in the challenge.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/2/23/22298199/california-net-neutrality-law-sb822 | title= California can finally enforce its landmark net neutrality law, judge rules | first = Sean | last= Hollister | date = February 23, 2013 | access-date= February 23, 2021 | work =[[The Verge]] }} The Ninth Circuit ruled unanimously in January 2022 that California's net neutrality law may continue to be enforced and cannot be overridden by the FCC as, current as of the decision, Internet services were classified as information services.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2022/1/28/22906856/court-upholds-california-net-neutrality-law | title = Appeals court upholds California's net neutrality law | first = Kim | last = Lyons | date = January 28, 2022 | accessdate = January 28, 2022 | work = [[The Verge]] }} The trade groups abandoned the case against the law by May 2022.{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2022/05/stung-by-3-court-losses-isps-stop-fighting-california-net-neutrality-law/ | title = Stung by 3 court losses, ISPs stop fighting California net neutrality law | first = Jon | last =Brodkin | date = May 5, 2022 | accessdate = May 5, 2022 | work = [[Ars Technica]] }} ====Save the Internet Act (2019)==== Democratic Senators and Representatives presented the Save the Internet Act in both Houses of Congress in early March 2019. The Act, if passed, would rescind the 2017 FCC order to repeal the 2015 Open Internet Order, codify the 2015 Open Internet Order into law, and prevent the FCC from making any similar changes baring any further change in law. Republican lawmakers indicated they felt this was too extreme and were unlikely to give support to the bill.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2019/3/6/18253176/net-neutrality-bill-democrats-law-fcc-house-senate-congress | title = Democrats push new bill to write net neutrality into law, but can it pass? | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = March 6, 2019 | access-date = March 6, 2019 | work = [[The Verge]] }}{{cite web | url = https://thehill.com/policy/technology/433738-gop-pushes-back-on-net-neutrality-bill-at-testy-hearing/ | title = GOP pushes back on net neutrality bill at testy hearing | first= Emily | last = Birnbaum | date = March 12, 2019 | access-date = March 15, 2019 | work = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] }} The bill cleared the House on a 232–190 vote on April 10, 2019, but both leaders in the Republican-controlled Senate and then-president Trump indicated they would stop the bill's passage.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2019/4/10/18304522/net-neutrality-save-the-internet-act-house-of-representatives-approval | title = House approves Save the Internet Act that would reinstate net neutrality | first = Makena | last= Kelly | date = April 10, 2019 | access-date = April 10, 2019 | work = [[The Verge]] }} ===Under the Biden administration (2021–present)=== With [[Joe Biden]] becoming president in January 2021, Ajit Pai announced his departure from the FCC in the same month. Biden named [[Jessica Rosenworcel]], an Obama-era appointee to the FCC, as acting chairperson. Rosenworcel was a vocal proponent for net neutrality in previous FCC rulings.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/21/22240827/biden-acting-fcc-chair-rosenworcel-net-neutrality-acting | title = Biden appoints Jessica Rosenworcel as acting FCC chair | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = January 21, 2021 | accessdate = July 9, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] }} On July 9, 2021, Biden signed {{ Visible anchor | Executive Order 14036}},{{cite web | access-date=2022-10-20 | year=2021 | last=Biden | first=Joseph R. | author-link=Joseph R. Biden| website=[[Federal Register]] | url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2021/07/14/2021-15069/promoting-competition-in-the-american-economy | title=Promoting Competition in the American Economy | id=FR Doc. 2021-15069}} "Promoting Competition in the American Economy", a sweeping array of initiatives across the executive branch. Among them included instructions to the FCC to restore the net neutrality rules that had been undone during the Trump administration.{{cite web | url = https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/09/biden-to-sign-executive-order-aimed-at-cracking-down-on-big-tech-business-practices.html |title = Biden signs order to crack down on Big Tech, boost competition 'across the board' | first1 = Kevin | last1 = Breuninger | first2 = Lauren | last2 = Feiner | date = July 9, 2021 | accessdate = July 9, 2021 | work = [[CNBC]] }} The resignation of Pai in January 2021 left the FCC at a two-two deadlock until September 2023, when Biden-nominated [[Anna M. Gomez]] was sworn in as the Commission's fifth member. Rosenworcel stated that month that the FCC plans to re-introduce net neutrality rules.{{cite web | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-09-26/fcc-aims-to-reinstate-net-neutrality-rules-as-us-democrats-gain-control-of-panel | title = FCC Aims to Reinstate Net Neutrality Rules After US Democrats Gain Control of Panel | first = Todd | last= Shields | date = September 25, 2023 | accessdate = September 25, 2023 | work = [[Bloomberg News]] }} While it is expected for the FCC to rule to restore net neutrality, a white paper published by telecom legal experts in 2023 warned that the rule will likely face challenges in the Supreme Court under the [[major questions doctrine]].{{cite web | url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2023/10/is-net-neutrality-doomed-at-supreme-court-fcc-and-isps-prepare-for-epic-battle/amp/ | title=Net neutrality's court fate depends on whether broadband is "telecommunications" | date=October 9, 2023 }} The FCC voted 3-2 on October 19, 2023, to approve issuing a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) seeking comments about rolling back to the 2015 rules. The commenting period was closed on January 18, 2024.{{cite web | url=https://statescoop.com/fcc-open-internet-net-neutrality-2024-nprm/| title=FCC closes comments on 'open internet protections' rulemaking |work = State Scoop | date=January 18, 2024 }} The FCC voted in these proposed guidelines on April 25, 2024, on a 3-2 vote, returning Internet services under Title II, enforcing net neutrality. Providers under the NCTA filed suit to challenge the new rule in June 2024. Under the suit, the providers questioned whether the FCC has the authority to reclassify broadband services. While this had been settled by previous cases like ''Brand X''{{cite web |date=June 5, 2024 |title=Broadband providers file lawsuits against FCC to crush net neutrality rules |url=https://www.techspot.com/news/103267-broadband-providers-file-lawsuits-against-fcc-crush-net.html |website=Techspot}} the ''Chevron'' deference central to these cases was overturned in June 2024 by ''[[Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo]]'', leaving in question the capability of the FCC to enforce its net neutrality decision{{cite web | url = https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2024/06/scotus-kills-chevron-deference-giving-courts-more-power-to-block-federal-rules/ | title = SCOTUS kills Chevron deference, giving courts more power to block federal rules | first = Jon | last = Brokin | date = June 28, 2024 | work = [[Ars Technica]] }} The Sixth Circuited granted a temporary injunction against the new net neutrality rules in July 2024, with a hearing to determine if a permanent injunction is necessary at an August hearing. {{cite web | url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/7/15/24199126/net-neutrality-rules-temporarily-halted-sixth-circuit | title=Appeals court halts reinstatement of net neutrality | date=July 15, 2024 }} On extending the stay in August 2024, the majority of the Sixth Circuit stated that due to the flip-flopping on how the FCC has classified internet services, it will be highly unlikely for the FCC to prevail using the weaker Skidmore deference. {{cite web | url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/1/24211570/net-neutrality-sixth-circuit-stay-blocked-fcc | title=Net neutrality is on ice | date=August 2024 }} With the election of Donald Trump for his second term as president starting in 2025, Rosenworcel will step down as chairperson of the FCC.https://www.reuters.com/world/us/rosenworcel-step-down-us-federal-communications-commission-chair-jan-20-2024-11-21/ Trump plans to replace her with [[Brendan Carr (lawyer)|Brendan Carr]], a sitting committee member, and is expected to name another Republican to fill Carr's position. Carr is a vocal opponent of net neutrality and supports aspects such as data caps, and believes that Internet service providers should be allowed to compete without regulation, differentiating their services to draw in customers.https://www.nytimes.com/2024/11/17/technology/fcc-nominee-brendan-carr-trump.html === Timeline of significant events === * January 12, 2003 – [[Columbia University]] law professor [[Tim Wu]] coins the phrase ''network neutrality'' in a paper calling for anti-discrimination rules to be applied to internet service providers. * June 27, 2005 – Supreme Court decides that The bill allows first response agencies to request, that mobile service providers not limit, or degrade, internet traffic of accounts used by the agency in response to emergencies.{{Cite web|title=Bill Text - AB-1699 Telecommunications: mobile internet service providers: first response agencies: emergencies.|url=http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201920200AB1699|access-date=2020-10-18|website=leginfo.legislature.ca.gov}} *October 27, 2020 - The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) votes 3-2 to reaffirm the rolling back of net neutrality regulations.{{Cite web|last=Klar|first=Rebecca|date=2020-10-27|title=FCC reaffirms order rolling back net neutrality regulations|url=https://thehill.com/policy/technology/522947-fcc-reaffirms-order-rolling-back-net-neutrality-regulations/|access-date=2020-11-02|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|language=en}} *February 8, 2021 - The U.S. Justice Department dropped its legal challenge to California's net neutrality statute.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/2/8/22273185/justice-department-drops-california-net-neutrality-lawsuit-ajit-pai|title = Justice Department drops challenge to California net neutrality rules|date = February 8, 2021}}{{cite web|url=https://docs.fcc.gov/public/attachments/DOC-369799A1.pdf |title=Statement of Acting Chairwoman Jessica Rosenworcel|date=February 8, 2021|website=fcc.gov|access-date=26 September 2023}} ==Violations== Many broadband operators imposed various contractual limits on the activities of their subscribers. In the best known examples, [[Cox Cable]] disciplined users of [[virtual private network]]s (VPNs) and [[AT&T]], as a cable operator, warned customers that using a [[Wi-Fi]] service for home networking constituted "[[Theft of services|theft of service]]" and a federal crime.[https://ssrn.com/abstract=388863 NETWORK NEUTRALITY, BROADBAND DISCRIMINATION, Tim Wu] Journal of Telecommunications and High Technology Law, Vol. 2, p. 141, 2003 Comcast blocked ports of VPNs, forcing the state of Washington, for example, to contract with telecommunications providers to ensure that its employees had access to unimpeded broadband for [[remote work]]. Other broadband providers proposed to start charging service and content providers in return for higher levels of service (higher network priority, faster or more predictable), creating what is known as a [[tiered Internet]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~raylin/tieredinternet.html|title=NET NEUTRALITY: tiered internet|website=www.ocf.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-12-17}} In 2005, North Carolina ISP Madison River Communications blocked the voice-over-internet protocol (VOIP) service Vonage. The FCC issued a Letter of Inquiry to Madison River, initiating an investigation. To avoid litigation, Madison River agreed to make a voluntary payment of fifteen thousand dollars and agreed to not block ports used for VoIP applications or otherwise prevent customers from using VoIP applications.{{cite web|url=https://transition.fcc.gov/eb/Orders/2005/DA-05-543A2.html |title=Federal Communications Commission Document|website=fcc.gov|access-date=26 September 2023}} According to the consent decree, "The Parties agree that this Consent Decree does not constitute either an adjudication on the merits or a factual or legal finding regarding any compliance or noncompliance with the requirements of the Act and the Commission’s orders and rules. The Parties agree that this Consent Decree is for settlement purposes only." In September 2012, a group of public interest organizations such as [[Free Press (advocacy group)|Free Press]], [[Public Knowledge]] and the [[New America Foundation]]'s Open Technology Institute filed a complaint with the FCC that AT&T was violating net neutrality rules by restricting use of [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]'s video-conferencing application [[FaceTime]] on cellular networks to those who have a shared data plan on AT&T, excluding those with older, unlimited or tiered data plans.{{cite news |title=Groups Prepare to Fight AT&T Over FaceTime Restrictions |author=Brian X. Chen |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/18/fcc-facetime-att |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 18, 2012 |access-date=October 26, 2012}} The FCC response noted that "Although this report does not attempt to engage in any legal interpretations of the Open Internet Order, we do note that the Order treats these mobile broadband networks differently from traditional fixed networks. While both fixed and mobile broadband providers must disclose their management practices, mobile broadband providers have greater latitude for blocking devices and applications (as long as they do not compete with the provider's own voice or video telephony services) and discriminating in how they serve traffic, in accordance with reasonable network-management practices."{{cite web |title=AT&T/FaceTime Case Study |author=Federal Communications Commission |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/cgb/oiac/Mobile-Broadband-FaceTime.pdf |date=August 20, 2013 |access-date=February 2, 2018}} ==Attempted legislation== {{Update|section|date=December 2021}} {{Main|Attempted net neutrality legislation in the United States}} Arguments associated with net neutrality regulations came into prominence in mid-2002 with nine different bills introduced on this issue between 2006 and 2013. Industry officials say that these proposals would launch new rules and regulations for internet providers. On October 22, 2009, Sen. McCain (R-AZ) introduced the “Internet Freedom Act of 2009{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/111th-congress/senate-bill/1836?s=1&r=39|title = S.1836 - 111th Congress (2009-2010): Internet Freedom Act of 2009|date = October 22, 2009}}” (S. 1836). The bill would prohibit the FCC from enacting rules that would regulate the Internet. In other words, the bill, if passed, would prevent the FCC from imposing network or “net” neutrality rules to the Internet. Specifically, the bill language states, “The FCC shall not propose, promulgate, or issue any regulations regarding the Internet or IP-enabled services. In other words, the bill, if passed, would prohibit the FCC from enacting rules that would regulate the Internet – or against net neutrality.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/advocacy/telecom/netneutrality/legislativeactivity|title=Network Neutrality Legislative History|date=November 2018}} On January 5, 2011, two anti-net neutrality bills were introduced. The first bill was H.R. 96, The Internet Freedom Act,{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/house-bill/96|title = H.R.96 - 112th Congress (2011-2012): Internet Freedom Act|date = February 2011}} introduced by Rep. Blackburn (R-TN), with more than sixty cosponsors (all of whom are Republican). H.R. 96 strikes down the FCC’s December 21 passage of its rule and order on net neutrality by asserting that regulation of the Internet is under the jurisdiction of Congress, not the FCC. The second bill, H.R. 166, The Internet Investment, Innovation, and Competition Preservation Act{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/house-bill/166/text|title = Text - H.R.166 - 112th Congress (2011-2012): Internet Investment, Innovation, and Competition Preservation Act|date = February 2011}} – was introduced by Rep. Cliff Stearns (R-FL) and co-sponsored by Rep. Blackburn. The bill also seeks to prohibit the FCC from regulating the Internet or information services (i.e. imposing net neutrality rules) unless there is demonstrated market failure. On January 25, 2011, The pro-net neutrality bill – S. 74, The Internet Freedom, Broadband Promotion, and Consumer Protection Act of 2011 {{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/senate-bill/74|title = S.74 - 112th Congress (2011-2012): Internet Freedom, Broadband Promotion, and Consumer Protection Act of 2011|date = January 25, 2011}}– was introduced by Sen. Cantwell (D-WA) and co-sponsored by Sen. Franken (D-MN). The bill would codify the FCC's six net neutrality principles (which the ALA supported), outlined in a November 2009 FCC Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM), among other things. ==Positions== There has been extensive debate about whether [[Net neutrality law|net neutrality should be required by law]] in the United States. Debate over the issue predates the coining of the term. Advocates of net neutrality have raised concerns about the ability of broadband providers to use their [[Last mile (telecommunications)|last mile]] infrastructure to block Internet applications and content (e.g. websites, services, and protocols), and even to block out competitors.Lessig, L. 1999. [http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/works/lessig/www9.pdf Cyberspace’s Architectural Constitution], draft 1.1, Text of lecture given at www9, Amsterdam, Netherlands While opponents claim net neutrality regulations would deter investment into improving broadband infrastructure and try to fix something that isn't broken.{{Cite web |url=http://www.tiaonline.org/sites/default/files/pages/Internet_ecosystem_letter_FINAL_12.10.14.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=December 16, 2014 |archive-date=December 16, 2014 |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20141216170749/http://www.tiaonline.org/sites/default/files/pages/Internet_ecosystem_letter_FINAL_12.10.14.pdf |url-status=live }}{{cite web |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/commentary/ct-internet-regulations-fcc-ftc-obama-broadband-perspec-0219-20150218-story.html |title=The Internet isn't broken. Obama doesn't need to 'fix' it. |first=Chicago |last=Tribune |website=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=February 18, 2015 }} In 2014 [[Susan P. Crawford|Professor Susan Crawford]], a legal and technology expert at [[Harvard Law School]] suggested that [[municipal broadband]] might be a possible solution to net neutrality concerns.{{cite news |last=Crawford |first=Susan |author-link=Susan P. Crawford |title=The Wire Next Time |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/28/opinion/the-wire-next-time.html |date=April 28, 2014 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=April 28, 2014}} ===Support of |url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2005/11/vint-cerf-speaks-out-on-net-neutrality.html |publisher=Blogspot.com |date=November 8, 2005 |title=Vint Cerf speaks out on net neutrality Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, the Decentralized Information Group|date=June 21, |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227100511/http://dig.csail.mit.edu/breadcrumbs/node/144 |archive-date=December 27, 2008 |df=mdy-all}} Other organizations that have voiced support for Net Neutrality are Facebook, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google. In December 2017 public opinion poll, 83% of voters supported keeping the rules on net neutrality, including 75% of Republican voters, 89% of Democratic voters, and 86% of independent voters.{{cite news |last=Neidig |first=Harper |title=Poll: 83 percent of voters support keeping FCC's net neutrality rules |url=https://thehill.com/policy/technology/364528-poll-83-percent-of-voters-support-keeping-fccs-net-neutrality-rules/ |newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=December 12, 2017 |access-date=December 14, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.publicconsultation.org/united-states/overwhelming-bipartisan-majority-opposes-repealing-net-neutrality/|title=Overwhelming Bipartisan Majority Opposes Repealing Net Neutrality {{!}} Program for Public Consultation|website=www.publicconsultation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-18}} Outside of the US, several countries have removed net neutrality protocols and have started double charging for delivering content (once to consumer and again to content providers). This equates to a toll being required for certain internet access, essentially limiting what is available to all people, in particular low income households.{{cite web |url=http://www.technologyreview.com/news/523736/around-the-world-net-neutrality-is-not-a-reality/ |title=In Developing Countries, Google and Facebook Already Defy Net Neutrality – MIT Technology Review |work=MIT Technology Review |access-date=February 26, 2015}} Large, already well-established companies may not be harmed by cost increase that providers such as Comcast may levy upon them, but it may stifle small businesses and start-ups.{{cite web |url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20140604/05594427450/entrepreneurs-explain-how-end-net-neutrality-would-mean-their-startups-dont-exist.shtml |title=Entrepreneurs Explain How The End of Net Neutrality Would Mean Their Startups Don't Exist |work=Techdirt. |date=June 4, 2014 |access-date=February 26, 2015}} Sites such as Facebook, Google, and Amazon may not have been able to thrive absent net neutrality.{{cite web |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/nathan-white/net-neutrality_b_5256423.html |title=Net Neutrality and the Future of the Internet |work=[[HuffPost]] |date=May 2, 2014 |access-date=February 26, 2015}} Barbara Stripling, the president of the American Library Association states: "School, public and college libraries rely upon the public availability of open, affordable Internet access for school homework assignments, distance learning classes, e-government services, licensed databases, job-training videos, medical and scientific research, and many other essential services, we must ensure the same quality access to online educational content as to entertainment and other commercial offerings." Previously existing FCC rules do not prevent telecommunications companies from charging fees to certain content providers in exchange for preferential treatment (the so-called "fast lanes"). Neutrality advocates [[Tim Wu]] and [[Lawrence Lessig]] have argued that the FCC does have regulatory power over the matter, following from the [[must-carry]] precedent set in the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] case [[Turner Broadcasting v. Federal Communications Commission]].{{cite web |url=http://www.freepress.net/docs/wu_lessig_fcc.pdf |access-date=2023-09-20|title=Ex Parte Submission in CS Docket No. 02-52|website=www.freepress.net |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070109101842/http://www.freepress.net/docs/wu_lessig_fcc.pdf |archive-date=January 9, 2007}} Net neutrality proponents argue that telecom companies seek to impose a [[tiered service]] model in order to control the pipeline and thereby remove competition, create [[artificial scarcity]], and oblige subscribers to buy their otherwise noncompetitive services. Many believe net neutrality to be primarily important for the preservation of current internet freedoms; a lack of net neutrality would allow [[Internet service providers]], such as [[Comcast]], to extract payment from [[content providers]] like [[Netflix]], and these charges would ultimately be passed on to consumers.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/07/AR2006060702108.html |title=No Tolls on The Internet |last=[[Lawrence Lessig]] and [[Robert W. McChesney]] |date=June 8, 2006 |work=Columns}}{{cite web |url=http://consumerist.com/2015/02/24/these-2-charts-from-comcast-show-why-net-neutrality-is-vital/ |title=These 2 Charts From Comcast Show Why Net Neutrality Is Vital |publisher=[[The Consumerist]] |date=February 24, 2015 |access-date=February 28, 2015 |author=Morran, Chris}} Civil rights organizations, such as the [[Color of Change]], the [[National Hispanic Media Coalition]], and more{{cite web |url=http://www.colorlines.com/articles/digital-equity-groups-explain-how-fcc-chairs-net-neutrality-rollback-will-hurt-communities |title=Digital Equity Groups Explain How FCC Chair's Net Neutrality Rollback Will Hurt Communities of Color |last=Rao |first=Sameer |date=April 27, 2017 |website=Color Lines|access-date=May 26, 2017}} argue that net neutrality is also important for communities of color because it allows for them to tell their own stories and “organize for racial and social justice."{{cite web|url=https://www.savetheinternet.com/net-neutrality-what-you-need-know-now|title=Net Neutrality: What You Need to Know Now|website=Save The Internet|access-date=May 26, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170522062528/https://www.savetheinternet.com/net-neutrality-what-you-need-know-now|archive-date=May 22, 2017|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}}  Much of the mainstream media does not showcase these minority people, so these organizations believe that it is important to open the Internet into giving these people some sort of broadcast station.  By doing so, their voices can be heard, because beforehand ISPs could “block unpopular speech and prevent dissident voices from speaking freely online." In May 2014, some websites admitted to inserting code that slowed user access to their site from known FCC IP addresses, as a protest on the FCC's position on net neutrality.{{cite magazine |last=McMillan |first=Robert |title=Websites Throttle FCC Staffers to Protest Gutting of Net Neutrality |url=https://www.wired.com/2014/05/fcc-throttling/ |date=May 16, 2014 |magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |access-date=May 16, 2014}} On his show ''[[Last Week Tonight with John Oliver|Last Week Tonight]]'', Oliver took on the issue of net neutrality for the first time in 2014, in the show's first season. [[Net Neutrality (Last Week Tonight)#"Net Neutrality"|The episode]] went viral with 13 million views on YouTube{{cite web |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/media/332113-what-john-oliver-wont-tell-you-about-net-neutrality/ |title=What John Oliver won't tell you about net neutrality |last=Balto |first=David |date=May 5, 2017 |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|access-date=May 26, 2017}} and prompted 45,000 comments on the FCC website.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2014/06/03/318458496/john-oliver-helps-rally-45-000-net-neutrality-comments-to-fcc |title=John Oliver Helps Rally 45,000 Net Neutrality Comments To FCC |last=Hu |first=Elise |date=June 3, 2014 |website=[[NPR]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150624041323/http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2014/06/03/318458496/john-oliver-helps-rally-45-000-net-neutrality-comments-to-fcc|archive-date=June 24, 2015|url-status=dead|access-date=May 26, 2017}} At the 2016 [[Consumer Electronics Show]], former FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler cited Oliver's episode as a turning point in the issue of net neutrality. “John Oliver took the ultimate arcane issue, Title II, and made it something that got people interested. And that’s good.”{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2016/01/fcc-tom-wheeler-broadcast-tv-spectrum-auction-1201677015/ |title = FCC Chief Sees "Spectrum Extravaganza" As TV Auction Deadline Approaches – CES | first = David | last = Lieberman | date = January 6, 2016 | access-date = January 1, 2019 | work = [[Deadline Hollywood]] }} Oliver returned to the issue of net neutrality on his [[Net Neutrality (Last Week Tonight)#"Net Neutrality II"|May 7, 2017, episode]] in response to Chairman Pai's promise to get rid of the regulation. He prompted viewers to once again comment on the FCC website by buying the domain gofccyourself.com, which garnered 1.6 million contributions.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/biz/news/john-oliver-fcc-net-neutrality-comments-1202427547/ |title=John Oliver Skewers Critics in Latest Plea for Net Neutrality |last=Johnson |first=Ted |date=May 15, 2017 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|access-date=May 26, 2017}} Some have referenced{{cite web |url=https://www.inverse.com/article/55798-spacex-starlink-how-elon-musk-could-disrupt-the-internet-forever |title=ELON MUSK'S STARLINK COULD BRING BACK NET NEUTRALITY AND UPEND THE INTERNET |last=Brown |first=Mike |date=May 13, 2019 |website=Color Lines|access-date=March 5, 2021}} the advance of Elon Musk's [[Starlink]] as something that could undercut the lobbying power of cable companies by offering internet access via satellite as opposed to traditional wired or wireless technologies. Some rural areas would have much less or no connectivity without net neutrality, making the use of farm software impracticable or impossible. {{ Cite web | year=2017 | website=[[The Counter]] | first=Sam | last=Bloch | url=https://thecounter.org/whats-at-stake-for-farmer-net-neutrality-broadband-access/ | title=While a fight unfolds to save net neutrality, rural America struggles to get online }} === Opposition to net neutrality === {{See also|Libertarianism in the United States}} Individuals against net neutrality include former FCC Commissioner [[Ajit Pai]],{{cite web |date=February 26, 2015 |title=Oral Dissenting Statement of Commissioner Ajit Pai |url=http://www.fcc.gov/article/doc-332260a5 |access-date=December 24, 2017 |publisher=Federal Communications Commission}} Daniel Berninger and [[Jeff Pulver]],{{cite web |title=Internet Pioneers Decry Title II Rules – Light Reading |url=http://www.lightreading.com/net-neutrality/internet-pioneers-decry-title-ii-rules/d/d-id/714129}}{{cite web |last1=Jenkins |first1=Holman W. Jr. |date=February 27, 2015 |title=The Net Neutrality Crack-Up |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/holman-jenkins-the-net-neutrality-crack-up-1425080173 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}} [[Marc Andreessen]], [[Robert Kahn (computer scientist)|Robert Kahn]], [[Peter Thiel]], [[MIT Media Lab]] founder [[Nicholas Negroponte]], Internet engineer and former Chief Technologist for the FCC [[David J. Farber|David Farber]], and Nobel Prize economist [[Gary Becker]].[http://faculty.chicagobooth.edu/dennis.carlton/research/pdfs/NetNeutralityConsumerWelfare.pdf NET NEUTRALITY AND CONSUMER WELFARE] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318194206/http://faculty.chicagobooth.edu/dennis.carlton/research/pdfs/NetNeutralityConsumerWelfare.pdf|date=March 18, 2015}} faculty.chicagobooth.edu{{cite web |date=January 20, 2011 |title=Back to the Future with Peter Thiel |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/257531/back-future-peter-thiel-interview |url=http://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2014/05/marc-andreessen-on-net-neutrality.html}}{{cite web |last=Negroponte |first=Nicholas |date=August 13, 2014 |title=Nicholas Negroponte: Net
